reviews.review: Hiddent gem. This is a hidden gem. The antique bhuda statues are superb. You can see it up close. Much better than many bhuda statues you can find in China.

What a wonderful place. A quiet and highly recommended escape in the noisy Hanoi. Beautiful expositions ranging from laqueurs to painting made on silk. Also well preserved stone and wooden engravings. Very happy we came here. Was quite impressed the art is not infused with revolutionary or war themes one would expect. Only one hall dedicated to that. Most of the art depicts people and nature. The whole tour on three floors will take you no more than 1.5 hours. If you manage to cross the street try the orange labelled coffee shop called Chat&Date.

Contemporary fused with history. The fine arts museum rapidly shifts from extremely historic pieces of dynasty art in Vietnam to contemporary fine art gallery displays. A great exhibit that is only let down by the somewhat state of disrepair of the museum itself.
A great place. If you like art. Really isn't my cup of tea, however the wife liked it a lot. Lots of interesting sculptures, paintings etc. If you are into art, this is a must see!!

worth the visit. it is well displayed and you can take your time to understand the history of vietnam. it takes you from the current times to way back in history. you need to spend quite sometime to really appreciate the beauty of this place. worth every dong paid to go in.
Historic and modern. Really cool that the museum takes you through a journey of Vietnam history from ancient times to modern day. Easy to negotiate your way around.

Fine Arts Museum. Located in the system of national museums in Vietnam, under the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism, the Vietnam Fine Arts Museum is considered one of the museum with the most important position in the retention and development promote the cultural heritage of the community arts Vietnam peoples. Founded in June 1966, the mission of the Museum is to study, collecting, exhibiting, preserving the heritage and art of the country to the public at home and abroad.

Go there: it's a delight!. Delightful place to spend a morning. In part, it illustrates how European techniques and concepts impacted on traditional Vietnamese art.VND300K to get in. And it's air-conditioned :)
Allow 2 hours+ plus here. A wonderful display that must have taken years to acquire. Many rooms full of Vietnam's incredible history.

A gem. This is our third trip to Vietnam and I don't know how we missed this gem of a museum. The museum is quiet large 4 floors and 2 separate buildings. It is a little hard to navigate but otherwise it is great. It is well lit, the explanations are in English, French and Vietnamese, and it is air conditioned. It encompasses several hundred years of art. It has a very interesting lacquer painting exhibition with good explanations. A little too much war paintings for my taste but then they have had many years of war.

Nice Window Into Vietnam's History and Culture . Stopped by on the way from Temple of Literature to the Citadel. In the modern day section I expected to be hit with lots of propaganda, but found much more than that. I had a glimpse into how the artists held on to their sense of what is beautiful through their nation's decades of struggle against outsiders. The one that especially drew me in is a work called "Lantern Festival" dated 1965 if I am not mistaken. I encourage you to see for yourself.

Excellent museum. Great place to visit, the artworks on display are well presented and vary greatly in style & subject matter.If I recall correctly there is kitchenware & art shop in the front courtyard that is also worth visiting.

Viva la revolucion!. As you'd expect, the vast majority of pieces here are from the last century, although there is a good collection of ancient artifacts as well. The aircon doesn't work very well, but the place is clean, typical of a Vietnamese museum. We thought it was well worth the visit, and it's close by Uncle Ho's mausoleum, so you can do it the same day. Recommended.

Gift shop - Beware when buying art. I spent 2 hours at the museum, it was incredible and I highly recommend it to art lovers. I then spent another hour in the museum shop and after much consideration decided to purchase a painting. The amount was agreed on and we discussed the additional cost of postage to Australia. Come time to pay the sales woman suddenly increased the price considerably. I was with my two adult children who witnessed this and were involved in the cost discussions. Sadly I didn't buy the painting and left feeling annoyed. I understand this is a common cultural experience when buying in Asia, however I did not expect this in such a setting and when the price was already considerable.

A neglected gem. This small but interesting collection of Vietnamese art is housed in a beautiful period villa. The collection includes a variety of works from very early eras to quite recent. I enjoyed the sculptures particularly. During my visit I only saw two other visitors! The gallery is airconditioned and was a pleasant respite on a sweltering day. One gets the impression that displays are quite static, but nevertheless I would probably make a return on my next visit to Hanoi.
Spirit and History. Some beautiful and moving sculptures and paintings. An emotional ride through Vietnam's spiritual and historical past.

Amazing Art. If you want to have a look inside the creative/artistic minds of art from Vietnam over the years, you have to visit this gallery. Various art styles throughout the gallery and for such a cheap entrance fee at that! Only $1.30 Canadian!!! The day I toured the galleries, very few tourists were there and I could savour each gallery quietly on my own. No rush to transition from gallery to gallery.

LOVELY COLLECTION OF CONTEMPORARY PAINTINGS. Amazing Vietnamese painters very reminiscent of the French impressionists. Cute still lives with local fruits. There is more old art in the history museum.

Very nice museum & gallery. This excellent Fine Arts Museum is housed in two buildings that were once the French Ministry of Information. Treasures abound, including ancient Champa stone carvings and some astonishing effigies of Guan Yin, the thousand-eyed, thousand-armed goddess of compassion. Look out for the lacquered statues of Buddhist monks from the Tay Son dynasty and the substantial collection of contemporary art and folk-naive paintings. Guided tours are available for 150,000d.
impressive. various fine arts on exhibition. nice place for those who appreciate and possibly find some ideas of creation
Better than other museums in Hanoi!. The building itself has a lot of character, and it is interesting to see the history of Vietnam through the evolution of their art.

my wife liked it, but not as good as similar museum in saigon. Lovely building, we went on a hot day and the place did not sell drinks, so our stay was not as long as it probably should have been. Admittance very cheap
Not much to see. A brief overview of Vietnam's art from antiquity to the 20th century. Not very informative- the artworks were not described or explained in any way.
fine arts in real terms. located in hanoi vietnam,its a museum showcasing fine arts of vietnam from a range of historic periods...
Moving pieces from the past. Very interesting to see Viet Nam's history through the eyes of artists. There are some very moving bronzes and stirring pictures here.

For Art lover or anyone who likes art and a bit of history.. We had a great time wondering here. There are 3 floors of Art, silk painted, sculpture, wood works both very old and contemporary and much more. We have learnt so much about Vietnam History and really admired it. The only let down was the flow of each room was a bit inconsistent, as if it needed a major renovation of the whole building and so able to rearrange the art works.Tickets can be purchased at the front gate for a small amount of money. It is also good in a rainy or super hot day.
Silent place with different stages pictures of Vietnam. Various stages of Vietnam and it is air-conditioned though it is not strong enough. But a nice place to know vietnam more.

Top museum in Vietnam. First, it's a very cool place to spend an afternoon on a hot day (which describes every day of my entire two week trip to the area). Most rooms in the museum are air conditioned, though bathrooms, stairwells, and one or two other areas aren't.Second, the price is right. Entry was 30,000 VND, which was less than $1.50, and I easily spent two hours there and would have enjoyed being able to spend an hour more. I rushed through the top floor and the second building, but if I had taken my time about it, I think it could have been a very pleasant 3 hour visit.Third, the art was pretty fantastic. The ground floor, in particular, with all the ancient art, was really interesting. The middle floor had some older work and some newer work- it's a little odd, but they seem to have organized the displays almost entirely by the type of medium instead of thematically or chronologically. For instance, there's one room of works on paper, and one gallery of work using laquer, and one room with works on silk. In a given room, there may quite a range of art. I think it would be a hard place to find a particular piece, but to wander around in, it was very pleasant.Some of the signage isn't translated very well, but there is at least some English signage just about everywhere, and you get the general idea.The ground floor of the main building was mostly older art, with many religious-themed items and quite a bit of sculpture. Upstairs one level from there is mostly paintings, a few sculptural pieces but much more emphasis on 2D artwork. There was a room or two on the middle level which I would characterize as Vietnam War propaganda art, and certainly the more contemporary art on the top floor had many pieces that were clearly influenced by the war or war propaganda- the victorious or courageous soldier portrait being a common theme.Don't neglect the second building, which is off to the left of the ticket office (the main building being straight ahead). It has a basement with ceramic art and a floor of household items, including clothing and decorated or traditional objects, which was all very interesting and I would have liked to have more time to explore.There weren't very many visitors there, though I was there on a weekday morning, so maybe weekends are busier. I had the feeling the guards outnumbered us, but it was nice not to feel crowded or rushed. The place was fairly quiet. In a way, it's too bad- people are missing out!I saw several museums in Vietnam, and this was definitely the best. Great art, English signs, air conditioning, for a tiny entry price.

A welcome respite from temples and pagodas. As much as I loved visiting Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum, Museum and grounds where he lived I loved viewing the great art diversity in one museum from modern to classic. Well worth the visit and it showed Vietnamese history in a different way. The building was well worth a visit in its own right, value again at 30,000VND a person

Cool off and enjoy the art. We visited this lovely museum on a hot hot day in a Hanoi, when we were all exhausted from the heat. It's quiet, cool, and the collection of sculptures and paintings through the ages just right for an hour's visit. We left feeling refreshed and ready to cope with Hanoi's busy streets again.

Don't miss for the price. At 30,000 Dong it is worth a visit to this gallery/museum, make sure you don't miss the contemporary art room hidden on the second floor. Although much of the art is very much the same throughout it is interesting to see the development of art styles as Europe's influence shapes the pallets and details. Then further how things change once the French are pushed out and Vietnam tries to find its own artistic identity.
Interesting. There wasn't a great deal of art there but what was there was well worth the visit. The ceramic display was amazing and in the coolest part of the building

A must see in Vietnam. For anyone who loves a bit of history and some great artwork this is a good place to start. Housed on three levels there is an array of etchings, statutes and paintings highlighting some of the great history of this country.

Recommended for a rainy day. I didnt have so much of expectation but it was nice enough to spend 2-3 hrs inside, especially the temporary exhibition was very nice . 2nd floor was definitely nicer than the first floor so dont give up too soon!
Not bad. The art is very big but I saw it quite small museum and may be can not show Vietnamese art it is foreign art in Viet Nam

History through artistic forms. Such a varied and well curated gallery. Some really impressive stone carvings and paintings - sculptures are thought provoking depicting more recent times. It seems the conflicts have shaped the VN psyche but also provided artistic expression. Cool oasis for reflection.

Very nice on a rainy day. This museum shows Vietnamese art through its centuries. I found it being very interesting as I didn't know much about it before we came. It's easy to see influences from other countries like Japan and China. The museum is bigger than I thought and it took us approx 2,5 hours, but we didn't rush it through so you can definitely go through it in 1 hour. But it was time well spent on a rainy day.
Art through the centuries well presented. We were so impressed with this museum as we were able to see the art of all of Vietnam as throughout the various periods and up to the present.

Gem of a museum in Hanoi. I had some spare hours before my flight, on Mondays many museums seem to be closed and we had already visited some of the main sights. I loved this, it was calm and peaceful. I saw some interesting unique art at my pace. I would recommend thoroughly. A visit to the gift shop resulted in some lovely souvenirs. I ended wishing I had more time !

Overrated. I was looking forward to coming her, but was disappointed. There are some interesting pieces, and there are some great bits of pottery towards the end. However, there is a lack of variety in the collection and a lack of developed explanations about movements and artists.

The museum of Nation!. I visited several of art museums in every country I traveled. Here is only museum where you can feel strong, rustic and groomy asmophere. I guess that's how here express their people.

An overlooked cultural surprize. After 4 trips to Vietnam over 10 years we finally made our way to this museum. We never realised it was just across the road from the Temple of Literature as it's not overly hyped. This is probably the reason we only saw a few other visitors during our hour and a half explore. The museum houses quiet a large collection: paintings, sculpture, textiles and ceramics. There could be better direction given, we did get a floor plan but tended to meander all over the place. There are lots of interesting art works, especially lacquer paintings and I really wanted to understand the lacquer painting process but info was scarce. The modern art section was small but interesting with a couple of pieces interesting enough to get me onto the internet back at our hotel to find out more. If you have plenty of time in Hanoi or are visiting the Temple of Literature you could add this one to your day and finish with lunch at the wonderful KOTO (Know one, teach one) restaurant, all within easy walking distance of each other.

A pleasant collection of contemporary artwork. The gallery is very peaceful and pleasant to visit. We were surprised that there wasn't more visitors! The collections inside are curated very well and demonstrate artwork from the early 20th century, traditional techniques and a small gallery of modern art. There were some excellent examples of war paintings and a lot of varieties of techniques such as engraving, wood cut prints, statues and oil paintings. There are captions relating to each room to give you a brief description of each collection. We really enjoyed seeing the modern/contemporary artworks and only wished there were more! I would recommend a couple of hours to see the gallery in full as there is a great deal of work.

You don't have to be arty to appreciate this. Several stories of galleries across two buildings. An excellent attraction to combine with the Temple of Literature.Wide ranging collection of art, with something that will appeal to all. We easily spent about an hour and a half here.Maybe not a must-see in Hanoi, but definitely worth a visit.
Loved this. I am an art fanatic and it was so good to see the works of many Vietnamese Masters.The tour will take up at least 2 hours including the ceramic display.Absolutely loved it.

Excellent Museum. Interesting collection of Vietnamese pieces, there is a significant collection of post 19th Century paintings that show the crossover East and West. Allow a couple of hours in this fine building

Very good for art lovers, add some modern galleries to your itinerary for a contemporary view. The Fine Art Museum has three levels with a good variety of work, from carvings, laquer paintings, to silk paintings and a small bit of more contemporary work. There are lots of interesting Buddas. The gift shop has some beautiful work too. On the whole there is a sentimental feel to alot of the more recent work, so I suggest adding in some contemporary gallery visits to your day to get an authentic voice from modern artists (e.g. Nguyen Art Gallery).
Worth visiting. Excellent collection of ancient and modern art and history. There are two main buildings make sure you visit both.

Waste of time. We have been address to this museum from the lonely planet. I believe there is nothing special in it! Nothing at all! You will be better off saving your time and do something else. Irrelevant!!

Great surprise!. while not planned, I decided to visit this museum passing by (and looking for a little bit of freshness). What a surprise to discover amazing paintings and laques. Art from 30's-40's particularly pleased me. I did not know very well laque work but they are really amazing there, as well as wood carving. The evolution or mix of technics between Asian ones and Western ones is also very interesting. And G/F with sculpture and statue also woth it. Just did not like the silk art. There is also 2 levels dedicated to decorative arts in VN daily life. I hardly recommand this visit.
Amazing. This is a secret highlight with 20 th century arts that are stellar. And you can take photos. A bargain and gem and much of it air conditioned.

Well worth a visit . The museum is in a very fine French colonial period building, just north of the Temple of Literature.
There are some fantastic Buddhist and Hindu works on the ground floor, and interesting lacquer works and socialist realist art from the modern period upstairs.
Items are well labelled in English.

Good mixture of the old and new. We had a lovely couple of hours here. There is a real mix of the ancient and the new. There is plenty of space for the exhibits and they have sufficient information. The newer collections reflects the country recent history with a high degree of propaganda running through, which is a nice antidote to the "hollywood" version of events. Only slight issue was the lack of a coffee shop. I would also recommend getting a taxi as its a little difficult to find and further out of the centre than the maps suggest.
Get a glimpse of Vietnam art. I was not expecting much but this museum is worth checking out. The art is unique to Hanoi. There is quite a large collection of art.

Curation a bit messy. You need some time to see all the artworks here. They aren't really organised in time as you walk up amd sround the floors, so it's not so easy to follow a timeline in the evolution of art. Interesting pieces, however, and you can see the change. Smells of humidity in most rooms.

Impressive collection of Vietnam fine art. This is a huge museum and needs to be visited in about at least 2,5 hours. Art collection of Vietnam from the Stone Age to contemporary art as well as Vietnamese traditional art. This is a good place for art lovers. Remember there are two exhibiting buildings and you should not miss the ceramic collection in the basement.
Nice museum.. This is Vietnam's primary art museum, showcasing fine arts from all different periods. It is worth a visit when you are in Hanoi. It also has a nice gift shop.

Very impressive. The ground floor introduction to the museum I found the most surprising. Some great stone carvings depicting people, deities and animals dating back to the 5th century display a love of art and storytelling. Most surprising was the early Hindu works before buddism arrived in Vietnam.The paintings works were mostly Somber works which is mostly from the French and American occupations so is understandable.

Nice curation over three floors covering over 2500 years of art history. We had just a few hours before we left for the airport. The Fine Arts museum was the perfect destination and a great way to end our trip to Vietnam. We spend a little over an hour and felt very good about our time there.
arts museum. great place to visit , allow yourself a few hours to see everything .So many great stories and fine arts to see
Beautiful Wood Sculpture.. Vietnamese wood sculpture is very beautiful. It is meticulous art work. I am glad that i went to fine arts museum (Bao Tang My Thuat).

Fantastic Museum. Brilliant laquer works and the mid 20th century paintings are superb depicting life during the French and USA periods. I would recommend this museum to anyone with a morning or afternoon to spare whilst in Hanoi.

Local art gallery. A spacious well ventilated, architecturally splendid building with displays on 3 floors of local art, ceramics and tribal customs. Entry fee VD30,000 which includes a free guide map to exhibits. There is a clear explanation to all items in Vietnamese, French and English. The historic periods cover prehistoric times to modern day. There is a gift shop on site but no eating or drinking facilities .
I had no idea abut Vietnames art, now I have. After the 80s, Vietnamese artists developed partly epigonist, but there are also very many surprising works (and a different use of the laquer technique)

Worth a visit, nice paintings collection... I enjoyed the beautiful collection of silk paintings and lacquer paintings for only 30 000 dengs. The museum has 3 levels dedicated to paintings and sculptures and there's quite a lot to see. There are also another small section in another building which exposed ancient ceramics, clothes and artifacts as well as midern temporary exhibition. The only issue is the limited explanation and only the year and the name of the object are mentioned. Also some of the exhibition rooms are not air conditioned and it can get hot. But a visit is still worthy.

Stunning. My favourite attraction in Hanoi. This museum has stunning collections of art throughout Vietnamese history, including some powerful war sculptures. Really enjoyed the lacquered wood, a beautiful influence from French art amongst others

Beautiful, and surprising. I was amazed and delighted by the art displayed here. It truly gives you a sense of Vietnam through the eyes of artists. There are some wonderful art works on display and it's worth visiting.
Very interesting and good expositions of works. We were here for about 1,5 hours and it was really very interesting. Good overview of the works. Good explication in both French and english

Vietnamese Art. We wandered in here on a whim and were really surprised by how much we enjoyed it. It is cool and calm inside which is an immediate relief from the city outside and there are several floors of paintings and sculptures on display. It showcases the diversity of local art and we found it quite fascinating. We were the only people there for the entire time we spent there.

An unexpected delight. This was not on our Hanoi 'to do' list, but we were on our way back to our hotel and were passing by when the gardens caught our attention. So we thought we would go in - and were so very glad that we did.This compares very well to good European museums in layout, lighting and information provided. It is not huge, but is probably larger than you first think it will be and if you have an hour or so it is a fantastic place to visit. It is well laid out with your visit going through the ages.Some (many) of the pieces are just superb and have an emotional impact to them and their history. Do not miss the separate wing after the (good) gift shop, this has astonishing clothing and other pieces. If you enjoy a bit of art/sculpture (historical and modern) this is highly recommended!
Exceptional!. Considering so much was destroyed by ongoing wars, this houses an impressive showcase of Vietnamese art from the 20th & 21st centuries.

Great for people who love the history. It is a good place to learn about the Vietnamese history through its historical masterpieces from past to present.
30.000 VND/person
very nice visit.. Lovely, A maze of rooms full of a variety of art works. Continue > signs guiding you through. A very nice visit.

MIX OF OLD AND NEW PAINTINGS. Enjoyed this place a lot. Very mixed displays of Vietnamese art, statues and artifacts. Layout meant it was easy to gt around. Not very busy so I presume it is rather overlooked, which is a shame
A comprehensive collection of Vietnam's art and sculpture. An interesting collection of Vietnamese art and sculpture through time. A well-appointed gallery by Asian standards.

Acquired taste. If you are into old and modern paintings then this is for you. If you are into more interactive museums then skip this. Lots of statues and paintings with explanations. We found it a bit boring and wish we had spent our money on the Hao Lo Prison instead. Fee is 30 000D pp, like most other tourist attractions in Hanoi. The saving grace for me was the smaller exhibit on historical artifacts and ethnic clothing. The wooden armoires inlaid with mother-of-pearl were exquisite.

Excellent and often neglected museum. Other museums receive more attention, but this museum in the embassy district within easy walk of the old quarters should not be neglected. The collection of ceramics in the basement floor is superb, and the paintings, textiles and other objets d`art are excellent. The entire museum demonstrates that Vietnam is more than ideology and recent military history. Take some time because the museum is larger than it appears. It is well laid out and most of the explanatory texts are in English as well as Vietnamese.
Great Collection of different times. Unexpectedly interesting. No guide required as the description were pretty detailed. It is a 20 minutes walk from old quarters. Closes at 4.30pm.

Excellent overview of Vietnamese modern art. Many touristic itineraries leave this excellent museum aside. It would, though, be a pity not to visit it, as one gets a complete picture of Vietnamese art in the last two centuries. Most of the paintings (mostly lacquer, but also oil, watercolour, silk) refer to the independence war, but there are a few contemporary paintings depicting daily life. One shouldn't miss the museum's souvenir shop, as one can find there several items of excellent quality at very reasonable prices.
Surprisingly Good Collection. Good place to spend a few hours to escape the rain or heat of Hanoi. They had a surprisingly nice collection of paintings and some very good buddhist and cham statues.

Great collection and great store!. Interesting collection covering many eras - not least an interesting contemporary collection. Also, make sure you visit the art sale room upstairs (one of two or three small stores there) which sells original works of art by living Vietnamese artists. Look and buy!!
Good for a rainy day. We attended with small children so it was difficult to keep their attention, they did enjoy the first floor statues, some beautiful works.
Beautiful collection and historical perspectives.. We enjoyed a lovely afternoon at this museum An amazing collection highlighting the rich history of Viet Nam.

Art works. Amazing. Works from many eras.
Some fantastic mediums. Sculptures of monks very special.
Shop sells local artists works for fair prices for original works. Bought marble box made up of 3 sections.Much dear in Old Quarter

good exhibit of modern art. the collection is quite interesting - almost french paintings - but with a lot of "war items" in the pictures and scultures
museum shop with good collection of books
Great variety of art. A great mix of art, well displayed on three levels. Perfect for a rainy day in Hanoi. Beware of replicas on some of the artifacts on the first floor.

Interesting Vietnamese Arts Museum. A small museum exhibiting some excellent vietnamese cultural works.
Nice artwork and paintings by Nguyen Van Ty and Huynh Van Gam (Miss Lien Painting) and statutes of Ms Vo Thi Sau by Diep Minh Chau and Nguyen Hai.
Worth a visit for the art works depicting the revolution from 1956 into the 1960s.

Worth popping by... At a mere 30.000 dong per person, it is a relatively cheap place to pop by. The only con I could think of, is that there are not many signs as to where you can see what. This is only a minor thing, and really, you can walk all over the place in the order you see fit :) we started from below, and worked our way up, in each of the two buildings. The different paintings are interesting, and especially the clothing and artifacts in the top floor of the secondary building was something I particularly enjoyed.The basement has a ceramic display, and then it is primarily is sculptures and paintings for the remainder. Really good place for a rainy day, or if you just need to spend a couple of hours on something different.
Nice small museum. A nice small museum with vietnamese art, near the temple of literature. Go if you have time. Cheap ticket.

Good place for a rainy day. If youre into art and history this is a great wee place. Both old and modern works.Spend around 1.5hours here.If youre walking from the old quarter to here, there are many really cool cafes along the way

Amazing place. Not sure why this place is not so popular among locals and tourists. I think this museum is one of the best museums I've ever been to. Very well-organized and nicely displayed. A lot of valuable piece of art was represented there. You can understand more about Vietnam art and how it changes from the old time to now. I love the modern art displayed there, they are colorful and eye-catchy. Worth my time!

Fine arts are always a must see!. A varied and interesting selection of Vietnam s artifacts, paintings, sculpture and many other works of art. On the second floor, the exhibition contains some of the county s best lacquer paintings and on the third floor there are many watercolor and oil works.

Beautiful setting for an interesting collection. We visited here 14 years ago and were dismayed to see so many of the art works open to the elements....but not now! The buildings have been refurbished beautifully, the galleries are well displayed and they have really excelled in their efforts to become a world class gallery.

An excellent collection of artwork.. Great presentation from all periods and media but perhaps the most impressive is the contemporary. It made us question why we Westerners still view this country as a "developing nation".

Very good museum. It's also huge - you could spend hours in here, and it comes as welcome relief from the heat and humidity outside. Strangely, perhaps because it's slightly out the way, there was virtually no-one here though.

The most important Fine Arts Museum in Vietnam. A small but stunning collection of fine arts arranged chronologically from the bronze age to the present. Do not miss the gorgeous rooms of 18th century larger-than-life lacquered wood sculptures of monks. There are English labels throughout. The small shop has some well curated books and gifts for sale. This visit really enhanced our understanding and appreciation of Vietnam's rich cultural history.
one of best museums of Hanoi. the biggest art museum in Hanoi where you can find different kinds of paintings from classic ones to quite contemporary.

Excellent Art Museum. With world-class collections, this fine art museum of Vietnam, located in Hanoi, is well worth a visit. Plan on spending at least two hours here to tour the many floors of art. Generally speaking the higher you go up in the museum, the more recent the art. My favorite pieces were on the top two floors, although each floor had many items worth visiting. This museum also boasts two very fine gift shops, from which we purchased many small paintings, prints, and lacquer ware at very reasonable prices for top quality work. I would strongly recommend visiting these gift shops for your souvenirs.
Interesting. Even Vietnamese find it interesting! Painting collections are quite interesting to me. However the museum does not display many prehistoric objects.

The best in Vietnam !. I've been to Art Museums in every city I've visited in Vietnam and this is by far the best! A wide variety of beautiful pieces which are all in excellent condition. They all have information tags and there are signs with history and influences (unlike other galleries). A very enjoyable experienceEntrance 40,000

Surprisingly good!. I just walked in this museum after visiting the Temple of Liturature but it turned out so great that I spent nearly 2 hours there. Very quite and academic museum with plentiful of art collections from the war time to modern life. I was attracted to the picture of Vietnamese women, I could feel the life and even imagine the story behind. The pottery display in the basement also a high-light of the museum. I want to recommend this place to all travellers who love arts and lacquer pieces. Well worth a visit!
Fine arts. Really nice gallery, with plenty of interesting exhibitions showing the history of Vietnamese art. Doesn't take too long to see it all either.

best of its kind in Vietnam. Hanoi fine art museum is the best of its kind in Vietnam. With the selection of pictures and statues, the Museum offer the visitors to learn about the development of Vietnam art since thousand years before until now. The museum also very easy to reach, if you visit the Temple of Literature, the Museum is just walking distance from this famous point.

An Interesting Art History Museum. A mostly chronological series of exhibitions, roughly divided into periods from the ancient to the contemporary, with some sectioning for specific genres (such as religious sculpture). Nicely curated, mostly interesting (though this varies, it was a little too heavy on the quasi-European late 19th/early 20th Century 'influenced' work, and not enough on the contemporary period for me), spacious, with a nice ambience. The gift shop is surprisingly good too. Get there early before all the hideous tour groups swarm the place out incessantly taking photos and talking loudly.

Pleasant surprise at the Fine Arts museum. After the craziness of the Temple of Literature across the street during Tet, we had a very pleasant surprise at the calm and quiet and excellent collection in this museum. It's all Vietnamese from works BC to present day. All well presented and very interesting. Don't miss the basement collection of pottery.

Visit FA Museum before buying street kitch. It was good to visit the museum before purchasing any of the street art on display. The museum offered a good appreciation for traditional art, as well as a better understanding of rate development of art in Vietnam in the 20thC.

Fine Arts Museum. Museum contained purely Vietnamese art from BC through to present day. Really interesting - showing sculptures, art reflecting the war in Vietnam as well as some more contemporary things.

Lots to see!. There is a lot of various artwork here that will keep your interest if you're into art or museums in general. The artwork is organized well and is pretty good. A lot of the woodwork is amazing. The gallery shows the development of Vietnamese art over time during different periods that affected Vietnamese life. If you can spare an hour and 40,000 VND, then I recommend that you give this place a visit.

Interesting Paintings. This museum is for art enthusiasts and historians. It is not particularly well maintained and the museum does not hold the best pieces master artists. Worth while to just visit for a sense of the cultural and artistic depth of the very good and creative paintings that Hanoi is known for.

A fair-sized building in the middle if town, it has three floors, all connected by stairs at either end of the spacious building. At each side of the impressive edifice there are both genders of toilets located helpfully just by the stairways. Each of the floors has multiple fair-sized rooms connected by various walkways linking the various different parts of the adequate structure. The floor surfaces continuously unite various different parts of the exhibits wrapping around in a meandering sense.Following an eight-year absence from the onset of the great recession, I returned recently to travel throughout Vietnam and Cambodia. Beautiful art collections. If you are at all interested in Vietnamese art, and not just the tourist pictures of girls in ao dai then a visit to the Fine Arts Museum is a must. There are some amazing sculptures from temples and collections of paintings that show the development of different styles of Vietnamese painting. Don't buy art in Hanoi until you have been to the Fine Art Museum, as the Museum Shop has a huge range on offer.
Great cultural overview. Very impressed with the depth of material at Fine Arts Museum from historical artifacts to contemporary exhibit.

if you are a fan of Fine Arts. if you are a fan of Fine Arts, this place must be in your list while being in Ha Noi. At first, there you can see pictures of modern images of Vietnam and at the same time old ones.

Lovely museum. We visited today on a cold rainy day. The museum was not heated at all and very cold inside. But what treasures inside! A lovely collection from the ancient to the 20th century. Much more well-cared for than the Fine Arts Museum in Ho Chi Minh City. A great way to spend a rainy morning.
very cool museum. museum is well curated and covers ancient to contemporary work from what is modern day Vietnam. the lacquer rooms were especially cool.takes about 90 minutes to see everything
Small collection with very interesting works. I would sincerely recommend this museum. They have a very nice, small collection of artworks that are rarely found in Vietnam!

Really cool art!. Follow a little history as you travel through the many, many floors and rooms of art. Cool sculptures, carvings, engravings, and paintings of traditional and modern methods! Very interesting art :)

An excellent reflection of history - even the kids enjoyed it. I did not expect this to be a highlight, especially with children aged 11 and 13. But I wanted to see it so I made them go. They actually really enjoyed it, as did I.As I said to the kids, art can tell you a lot about the culture and history of a place. Often it is only through artwork that we know some parts of history. In this case the more modern artwork was heavily influenced by the various conflicts, especially with the French and the Americans. My favourite pieces were the lacquer engravings, where they started with a black surface and the cut in the design and added colour.

Worth a visit.. A very good museum/gallery with exhibits spaced over three floors. The first floor has examples of early Vietnamese art from the 11th to 19th centuries, the second floor is for art of the first half of the twentieth century and it is worth pausing over depictions of the hostilities against both the French and Americans some of which looks to be naïve art and very striking. On the top floor there is a contemporary exhibition which is good in parts with some examples of socialist realism art.
Good collection. The French colonial building that houses the gallery is beautiful. The Gallery has a good collection of Vietnamese art overlast couple of centuries

Pleasantly Surprised. Often I don't like Asian art (particularly styles like Japanese paintings). This museum had a really good range of paintings and statues etc that kept us occupied for about an hour. If you have the time an are in the area, I would recommend stopping in. Many of the paintings from the last century depicted the war in Vietnam in many ways which was really interesting.

Are you a Psychologist or an Academic?. I was so looking forward to this visit. I just recently made my second visit to MOCA in Bangkok which is such a spectacular showcase for (Thai) homegrown art. So after choosing to visit the Fine Arts Museum in Hanoi, I arrived with great expectations which were shattered as soon as I walked in. This museum is testimony to the repression, intellectual and artistic, that was endured during the Communist regime. It might be recommended for psychologists and academics. Not to the general public.Art galleries in various cities in Vietnam exhibit pictures by a generation of talented, creative and inspired artists. None of this energy is found in the Fine Arts Museum. I have read very favorable comments by previous reviewers, so what do I know?!! I'm just Joe Shmoe from Kokomo

Another censored tourist attraction. About 95% of the works in this museum would not normally see the light of day in any self-respecting gallery in the Western World. Having said that, consideration must be given to the challenges facing artists in a communist society. There are some early art works that indicate that there might be more fine art works hiding in the vaults in the basement. The remainder tends to be about the struggle for independence with some very "Dark" exhibits in colour and themes. Censorship has demonstrated here what suppression can do to aspiring artists.

Fascinating but underappreciated. I’ve always like this museum, but I appreciate it more for its quirks than for its instructional qualities. The exhibits are arranged chronologically, beginning on the ground floor with the requisite nod to the Dong Son civilization and continuing on to more recent works on the upper floor. There’s also an adjacent building with textiles and ceramics. The wall texts are largely limited to dates, locations, and media. There isn’t much interpretive material provided in any language, and what has been translated into English can be incomprehensible. Despite that, visitors can still get a sense of major trends in the history of Vietnamese art. Visitors familiar with modern Western art will recognize the influence of Chagall, Picasso, and others in some paintings. The combination of European techniques and traditional materials, such as silk and lacquer, is striking. The museum lacks contemporary art, which can be found elsewhere in Hanoi at nonprofit and commercial galleries.Our taxi driver couldn’t find the museum at first. It’s across the street from the park containing the Temple of Literature (Van Mieu), which locals are more likely to know.

Peaceful environment with striking pieces . I was thoroughly pleased with my visit. Not only were there no crowds to navigate, the calibre of art was outstanding. I found myself taking pictures of piece after piece. Definitely not to be missed if you are in Hanoi. Make sure to check out the pottery in the basement too!

Pleasantly surprised--also includes traditional textiles and clothes. Well presented, larger than expected, included textiles and traditional woven clothes. The museum in a beautiful colonial building, and the upstairs hallways themselves present great lighting in the afternoon for good photography. The gift shop sold original works from Vietnamese artists (such as local university Art Professors) for prices starting at 3 USD!

Peaceful Environment. Near the frenetic activity of the streets of Saigon is this fine facility. It is a good place for some peace and quiet after the frenzy of the streets outside. Various periods of art are represented which give a good appreciation of Vietnamese art, such as lacquer art.

Interesting to see Vietnamese art develop through the centuries. After so many years of war, Vietnam is finding its way to make its own artistic expression in modern times--from the political art, to some that reflects the "masters" (impressionists, dada), it is interesting to find how artists are finding their voice appropriate to their own culture in modern times.

Outstanding. This museum and gallery is a combination of The V&A, British Museum and National Gallery in miniature. It has some excellent exhibits. It's collection of war period paintings is particularly strong. The signage is good. It is a modest 30k dong (less than £1) to get in. It is near The Temple of Literature, so great to "do" as a combo.
Large museum great for rainy days. Very lovely museum with a lot to see. Several floors. Check out the modern exhibitions first if you can.

Hard to find but worth the trouble. 68 NGUYEN THAI HOC STREET, HanoiNot an easy place to find. It’s in and about the diplomatic quarter in Hanoi. We wiggled and winded our way around until we kind or looked up and saw it. I am sure a taxi or hotel concierge would be helpful but we were already out on a self directed walking tour and wanted to meander anyway. The rotating exhibit was in progress/installation so we did not see that but the permanent exhibitions were a delight to see and the buildings were just brilliant to walk through. Well restored/preserved so to speak & nice staff. I had not seen lacquer painting before, at least not as a legit art genre, didn’t even knew they existed as such and was I ever impressed with the technical skills and composition and colors/textures, use of eggs shell of that style/medium. I was so impressed with the medium that I sought a gallery in Hoi An and bought a lacquer painting from an artist. Cost for the VNFAM is 30 VND. Clean toilets inside.
Wonderful Museum. I actually spent far more time here than I had planned. Some of the dislYs were so well done, and so interesting.
Worth a visit.. Very interesting insight into Vietnam's history and culture that is definitely worth a visit. Very quiet when we were there with few people.

Art about and by Vietnamese. Though on the small size, this well laid out museum is a gem. Ancient artifacts are on the first floor and then ending with modern times on the third. The influence of the prevailing style (ie. Cubism) makes an appearance and images of war find a place on the walls.

Wonderful. If you like art, if you are interested in revolutionary art, if you like ceramics - you are going to love this museum. It was on our list of things to do but, to be honest, I wasn't expecting too much. The first day we went it was closed due to there being 'no electricity' oh well... We went back today, paid our 40,000 Dong and boy! I'm glad we did. The collection of paintings and sculptures alone make it worth visiting. Three floors of beautiful oils, engraved lacquer and gouache works (mostly inspired by Vietnam's struggles), a few sketches and quite a few sculpted figures make this museum a must see. There is also a wing of ceramics which is worth a view. The souvenir shop Is nice but a little expensive and the restaurant, (shown on the site map) closed a year ago. Much, much better than I had anticipated. I would visit it again if we were staying longer.See it!

Good collection, but.... It is a very classic museum, in the sense that is a collector museum with almost not interaction with the visitors.  Here you can enjoy a cultural heritage, where struggling, working, and honor of Vietnam are the key subjects, as well as landscapes, and habitat,  The sad spot in this museum is the art preservation. I felt that they don't really care about conservation-restoration of this fabulous cultural heritage. Paintings look like they are full of adherent surface deposits, the colors of the lacquer paintings are faded and many of them have lost their gloss, and you can see moisture stains in many of the works on paper. Maybe there is no enough budget to preserve and treat the artwork. It is really heartbreaking.

I go here every now and then. I have seen the regular exhibition many times with various people. Ina a sense, it is not very impressive. However, it does impress me. Having studied Russian socialist realism in the States, it was interesting to see a new view of this that is, indeed, culturally different from the former Soviet Union. Yes, the themes are the same; however, lacquered painting is both difficult as well as a true technique requiring great skill. You see a lot of this here. Look at the characters. Sense their fears, hopes and dreams. We are not much different, really. If there is a special exhibition there, do see it. You will see Vietnamese modern art and where it is going today. So many of the modern art shows are for commercial sales. Here, you see the real stuff and no salesmen! You get the time to become familiar with each piece, to relish it and to walk away with some very good feelings.
nice. nice place! nice collection! the building is nice too! you can see different type of local art so it's really interesting

Make time in your schedule for this. This is an amazing exhibition.I'm not the experiences museum person, but I likes spending a few hours in this museum.There was such a diversity that you're bound to stop at some places because you like what you see.I lived the sculptures and some of the paintings were quite amazing to see.Some of the photo exhibition pieces were pleasant to spend some time on.Time : take at least 2 to 3 hours to go through all (could be more)

Give yourself time to explore this collection. I only had an hour to enjoy this beautiful collection. I knew nothing about Vietnamese art entering but was blown away by the range and depth of the collection I found the modern lacquer paintings stunning. Given the country's history there are unsurprisingly many war paintings. Give yourself two hours at least in this calm oasis in busy Hanoi

Excellent collection. Excellent collection of abstract paintings as well as pictures. Worth a visit if you have inclination towards arts. The modern art basically depicts the culture of the locals apart from abstract concepts.

A Gem!. This museum is set in the former home of a wealthy Hanoi resident. The collection is somewhat eclectic, but interesting just the same. There are a few artists' galleries located on the compound. Worth a look-see!
Good museum. A great place to know about Vietnam fine art history, all the famous painters and theirs works. What a pity Vietnam doesn't have a real art market nowadays

Back Again. I took my group of 10 for a very enjoyable day out to this part of town. Combined with Craftlink, KOTO and the Temple of Literature - all close by, makes for a superb day. The museum is not the greatest in the world but it has many fine exhibits and is well worth a visit particularly as it is so close to other (the above) attractions. The museum shop is also worth going to. They have some lovely prints etc at very good prices. Look for the signs on the left side - it's not very easy to find.
A find !. We were not planning to visit but on passing we were curious .Thank goodness for curiosity ! Beautiful building with a diverse collection of art works .

No need to rush. I have now been twice to the Fine Arts Museum. The first time with a friend was a bit rushed, so a few years later by myself, the second visit was slower. I enjoyed the cultural experience. I purchased a painting at the gift shop by an artist from the Fine arts Museum, it was very reasonably priced. I was lucky to be able to buy another by the same artist on my second visit for my daughter. Include a visit to the Temple of Literature a short walk away. I did not know it was so close and missed out both times. From the Old Quarter, we took a taxi the first time and I went on the back of a motor bike the second time. The bike was a lot more fun.

Good historical overview - and great art.. The museum has a more or less chronological exhibition of Vietnamese art with different themes and techniques going back to pre-history until present. I enjoyed the different techniques like lacquer painting and lacquered wooden sculptures. We also saw an exhibition about Japanese photography in the second building, that also has a ceramics section in the basement that is easily missed, as is also the shop just outside the 2nd floor of the main building.

A good overview of vitnamese art. This pristine gallery has very few visitors, which is a pity. Though it is presented in a politically correct, revisionist postwar way, one can see through that to the real quality of the work, especially of the early 20th century. And the Buddhas are fun. Colours are dark and nonwestern, odd at first to our eyes but they grow on you.

Different to the West. The Vietnamese defenition of Fine Arts is very different from the West. Mainly paintings from the middle of the last century up to today. It is probable that paintings have been carefully selected (vetted) to follow a strict historical interpretation so what is on show look like politically motivated, nationalistic images. This does not detract from the quality of the works many of which are exceptional using different media and artistic techniques. However, this museum is well worth a visit. We would like to see more publications on what is exhibited. There is also a gallery where you can buy contemporary art works but take care to ensure these works are originals.
paintings mostly depict changes in 1960. worth a visit if one is around old quarters and wants to walk around the city to come and come here for a short stroll.

Fantastic collection of paintings, ceramics and textiles. A great experience moving through 30 rooms of Vietnamese art from 'caveman' days through to the 21st Century. Particularly impressive collection of 20th Century art from across Vietnam. Highly recommended.

Excellent Museum! . I was so impressed by my visit here. Stunning work on all 3 levels, starting with ancient artefacts on the lower level going up to beautiful lacquer paintings, touching and disturbing war time paintings alongside world class impressionist style portraits and landscapes. There are also some masterful sculptures. Worth a look for anyone but an art enthusiast could spend many, many hours here. Lovely clean building with good toilets and air conditioning. Only 40k dong entry fee. Make sure you visit when in Hanoi. (Also be sure the visit the separate building on the left of the museum to see the collection of ceramics and a temporary exhibition space)

Best overview of Vietnamese art. The sections on Buddhist statuary, paintings in lacquerware and ceramic pottery should not be missed. There is a (too small) section on contemporary painting and also a good exhibit of ethnic minorities’ crafts. A no-brainer on a rainy day, but highly recommended even on a sunny day. Conveniently close to the Temple of Literature.

Very interesting Vietnamese art. It's quite a trek to the fine art Museum, and those who are organised it will combine it with a trip to the Temple of Literature. We walked here from the French Quarter, so were hot and sweaty on arrival. Once inside it was a cool haven of tranquility.All of the art is Vietnamese. It covers both ancient and modern. Much of the modern focuses on the wars, but it is very beautiful - including prints, lacquer, oils and watercolours. There's a good shop too.

Amazing Glimpse of VN Culture. The Fine Arts Museum is 3 floors of vietnamese history and culture. The ground floor is the oldest art, and it gets more contemporary the higher you go. They have quite a nice gift shop with pictures and reprints you can take home for not too much money.

See the evolution of art in Vietnam. The artwork at this museum runs in a chronological order, giving you an idea of the evolution of Vietnamese art from neolithic times through Chinese domination, French colonisation, and finally communist rule.The "modern" art in the museum are technically excellent, but the subject matter can be rather typical and sterile *cough*propaganda*cough*, so the temporary exhibit of the art by Nguyen Ngoc Dan was a refreshing change to me.The museum is near the Temple of Literature so you can combine the two sites in a single visit.
Communist art. The museum is basically filled with old Buddha statues and communist arts (e.g. from the war). A nice way to get away from the chaos for 1-2 hours, it is quite hot inside though.

Another Perfect Place to Learn About Vietnam. Affordable entrance fee. Interesting exhibits. It was my first time going to an art museum like this and I did not expect I would enjoy my one-hour visit there. Perhaps the artwork could be displayed in a more specific order or something but this museum is still worth the visit. Highly recommended. I am happy I squeezed in a visit to this museum during my short stay in Hanoi. Through the exhibits, I learned more about Hanoi or Vietnam - imagining how it may have looked like many years ago, admiring the paintings/sculptures, and not a second of my time was wasted in vain :)

INTERESTING COLLECTION OF LOCAL ART. Being an Asian art lover I was interested in seeing this museum.A lovely collection from early Vietnam up through the Vietnam of today.Quite interesting to see how the subject matter has changed through the years.

Shameful museology. The ancient pieces are very interesting, but displayed in quite a random order and in a manner that doesn't do justice to the objects. The modern paintings are chosen with a lot of biases, with too many political pieces and not enough leading artists (maybe a question of budget?) The best part is the religious section, with some rare representations of the pre-Nirvana Buddha. That alone makes the visit worthwhile.

I wouldn't go out of my way. A caveat: In general, I'm not that interested in older artifacts.
Overall the prevention of the older artifacts and and newer art needs a refresh. They aren't well lit and need maintenance.
If you're in the neighborhood it's worth checking out for the lacquer paintings, if nothing else, but there wasn't anything I considered a "must see"

Well worth the visit. This place is certainly worth visiting, and I spend an interesting 90 minutes looking around. All exhibits have an explanation in Vietnamese, French and English.
It was very quiet when I was there (I purposely picked lunch time for this reason), so I had most of the place to myself.
30,000 dong well spent.

a super collection. a nice place to visit; the museology is a bit out of date, but its only a matter of time before it catches up to the standard of the other leading museums in ha noi. And the collection is amazing.
Fine Arts Museum. An interesting mixture of old and more modern,with lots of bronze sculptures. It was a good way to fill a rainy morning.

A surprisingly Great Museum. This museum was by far the best I've been to in Asia. Set in a big old house and was a great relief from the scorching heat. All of the rooms were air conditioned, virtually empty so it was quite relaxing. If they ever make another night at the museum I hope they do it here. A great range of art, no docent to follow you around telling you not to take pictures. Overall a very wonderful visit and I can't wait to go back.

Shop Worn & Provincial. Although much of the art in this museum is beautiful, it is all Vietnamese and much of it is in need of some TLC. The museum is only air conditioned in some spots and the beautiful artwork is at the mercy of the oppressive heat and the bright lights.

Such a great place to visit.. It took us several hours to go round. Very interesting place with good info in English in the rooms. Covers a range of eras and styles. We really enjoyed it. There are more rooms out the side on the second floor I think it was from the door that goes to the gift shop.

A fine experience, nothing spectacular. Don't go expecting a comparative experience to a major metropolitan fine arts museum. The ancient art was very interesting, but the modern section wasn't the greatest. Very small, but worth the trip at $1.5 US

A major surprise in Hanoi. The work is fascinating, though the building is musty and in disrepair. There is a clear preference for traditional Asian media and methods, yet there's also a clear connection with Western artists of the time. Work that demonstrates the public mood of the war is particularly intriguing.
Art for arts sake.. Loved this museum. Only 30,000 Dong and you spend a couple of hours. Really gave me a good perspective of the History of Buddhism, culture and artistic excellence.

Fine arts Museum, Fine.. Just fine... For you art lovers, artists, and travellers who are into history and artistic local culture thing, this place is a must. It's a fancy museum which has a lot of fine arts inside. They were really nice.... I love the ambience.. So fancy.. And hence the name is fine, so it is fine..

Excellent!. Of all the places I explored in Hanoi, this was by far among my favourites! Such an incredible and diverse collection of all things artistic (I'm talking statues to paintings to jewellery boxes to quilling pieces and everything in between) that well represented Vietnam's unique and beautiful culture.

Ceramics and applied arts at the Fine Arts Museum. We had to rush through the Museum but could have spent 2-3 hours - especially in the airconditioned rooms. The very large collection of lacquer paintings were interesting, but the applied arts section showing the different handicrafts, embroidery, etc. used on articles was really wonderful. Downstairs in the area closest to the road was a wonderful ceramic display so make sure you go to both sections of the museum

Arts museum. Entry was free due to national holiday on 2/9 but worth a visit anyway. We went through in an hour or so. Would have been nice to see more contemporary art, because the lite they had was amazing.

More travellers should know about this Fine Arts museum. This museum displays a fine selection of sculptures, propoganda, paintings from early to modern times. Don't miss the ceramic exhitition down in the basement of the left buiding, this section is often easily missed. When I visited, there were only 3-4 other tourists on each floor. It seems like people are not paying a proper amount of attention to this gem. On the bright side, it is very quite and we can really focus on comtemplating the arts.

Propaganda arts. If you look for propaganda arts, this is a place for you. The layout is a bit confusing though.It looks like the museum is working on adding more "free thinking" arts. This shows went you go to the "folklore" section. In comparison to the value of Soviet propaganda arts in recent years, I believe that some of the paintings in this museum can be very pricey in near future.

INTERESTING LOCATION. Hi Guys, Just finnished my short trip on 2 hours in The Fine Art Musseum. I have some ideas as: - Tranquarity indoor and wide area outdoor.- Friendly Staffs- Clean- Diversity of Vietnam information about History.ư- Location is so near from French old quater area.Beside:Air Conditioner was be stopped. Out of electric is reasonable explaintation from some ladies there.There are alot of common and same subject with other musseum i have ever seen in Hanoi.
Better than I expected. A pretty decent collection of local art. Three floors of old sculptures and paintings from nearly a thousand years ago until the early 2000s.

Fine museum. Fine overview of art from the 70-ies, a Vietnamese perspective on the war, on oppression, much propaganda art of limited artistic value.Also some ancient sculptures, great examples of lacquer painting. A bit tiring to visit room after room lined up along long corridors.

Decent museum.. Way better than its HCM counterpart. Forgettable first floor with copies and reproductions. Second and third floors, a few good pieces but whoever curated made a terrible job, Everything scattered around with little sense beside a (vague) chronological order. Two small and very surprising rooms with some pieces from the vietnamese contemporary scene. This part should be expanded. Blows out of the water the national art museum in Saigon.
Amazing art.. This is a great place to spend a few hours looking at the various styles of Vietnamese art, and the motivations and influences that have shaped it.

Pretty good. Visit the Viet Nam Fine-arts Museum (Bao Tang My thuật) to see modern and ancient fine art. Its very close to the Temple of Literature meaning you can probably spend a day doing both sites and in between you can eat at Koto training restaurant which is also very close by. Crossing the street between the two places can be fun as its a very busy area. Although they have ceiling fans the fine arts museum it can get pretty hot if the weather is warm. The secondary building (to your left as you enter the gates) has aircon yipee so pop in and see the folk art and ceramics collections as well as textiles.
Great collection of art. This is a must-see. Lots of great artwork. My favorite were the contemporary arts. The historic artworks are very interesting too but too many of the same things.

Decent museum. Depending on how much you like your art you could spend 3+ hours here. The main building is mostly revolutionary paintings besides the bottom floor of ancient sculpture. There's also a small section of modern art here. Make sure to visit the secondary building (to your left as you first enter the gates) which for me was much more interesting, it has the folk art and ceramics collection as well as textiles. There's also better a/c in this building!Everything is signed in English/French/Viet and it feels like a proper museum.
Worth a visit. Great museum, much better than expected. Definitely worth a tour if you're around. Our daughters also very much enjoyed it.

Great examples of imaginative Vietnamese contemporary art. Great collection of Vietnamese fine art from traditional prints and folk art to impressive contemporary laquer paintings and sculptures - also air-conditioned so a great way to spend a hot afternoon.

Quiet beauty, sometimes cool. In the middle of the day, when many Hanoians are resting (including a few of the gallery monitors) we found this a welcome respite from the bustle of the streets and our schedule. We opted to visit from the top down, taking our tour backwards in history. The upper galleries were nicely done, and we particularly enjoyed the silk paintings and some of the modern works of sculpture and art. Although the galleries are air-conditioned, several of the AC units apparently were not working, so we paused not at all in the lacquers and early 20th Century paintings. The influences of East and West, traditions, history and socialism make for a fascinating study in this museum. While we could have stayed much longer, and will certainly return we felt it the ideal place for an afternoon wander through the soul and heart of Vietnam as seen by its artists.

Excellent art works particularly the revolutionary struggle pictures. Found this museum very rewarding some of the artwork covering the revolutionary period were evocative and really revealing. The museum is calm and well laid out, I was really glad I visited

This is a good art museum BUT. This museum is set in an old mansion. It is surprisingly well set up. The art is well spaced out. And there is some air conditioning. The museum has a fabulous selection of modern and contemporary art. HOWEVER, the art is not the most well preserved or maintained. If you have been to Europe or some of the world's top museum, this will bother you. The mats on the frames are dirty and stained. The glass on the frames are smudged with fingerprints and dirt.But if you can get past this lack of upkeep, the museum is a good way to spend an hour or two.

Neat art museum, from ancient to modern. A little hokey at times.. Starting with some brilliant old stone and wood sculptures, moving on to European influences, propaganda paintings, and 21st century wildness, this museum has a bit of everything. I did find the war era stuff a little corny for my tastes.What I found strange, is that the gift shop has tons of original art for sale, much of it more interesting than some of the stuff in the main building. I'd love to see that hanging in someone's house, but I couldn't get a straight answer on the prices. If you like ceramics, textiles, folk art etc don't forget to check out the smaller building on the side- it has two separate entrances.It's also air conditioned, so you can take a break from the heat while you absorb some culture and history!

Nice collection. Museum is worth to visit if You are interested of local art. Its very different from this, what European eyes are used to see. Museum is quite spacious and AC is very good inside so You can enjoy art in good atmosphere

Don't miss this spot!. I almost took this spot off the itinerary but thank god I didn't. We spent 2 hours here and it was of our favorite attractions in Hanoi. Incredible ancient art and 15th and 16th century carvings plus a stunning folk arts collection. Check out the gift shops for great gifts to bring home to your people,

Some incredibly pieces of art and a real "close-up" experience. There are some amazing pieces of art in the collection. We had limited time and rushed our walk through the museum to be able to take everything in. Leave a full morning/afternoon if possible. We loved seeing the unique pieces and given most pieces aren't behind class and you can literally walk right up to them. They allow photography (disappointingly even flash photography) of all exhibits. It's an experience you won't get in most national museums. On the negative side, they've not taken many (any?) precautions to protect the art pieces (some areas weren't even air-conditioned) and you could see the toll the humidity and touching is taking.

beautiful collection. There is a little bit of something for everyone here who appreciates art. Nice Colonial building, with items nicely spaced out in different rooms & levels. I particularly enjoyed the artwork. Well worth a visit.

Very informative and attractive museum!. It is about 10 minutes by taxi from the First Hotel or you can walk (about 20 minutes).It is located in the embassy area with French designed buldings.The museum presents various paintings of the Vietnamese authors in the past and at present. You will be thrilled with collections.

Beautiful fine arts museum. The first floor in the main building has a fascinating display of antique artefacts dating back up to a thousand + years, gorgeous and awe inspiring art. the second floor is mainly "propaganda & war" art which is an insight into this dark period of Vietnam's recent history which reflects the turmoil in the country during so much of last century. The 3rd floor has an enthralling display of Silk painting and modern art. A separate building houses non-permanent displays. We where enthralled by the displays and anyone with an interest in art 7/or history shouldn't miss this museum
Fine arts museum tour. Comprehensive and a collection of both modern and classical pieces here. I really enjoyed it despite being a relative fine arts bogan!

If you like art visit the fine arts museum. The fine arts museum offers a good historical perspective of Vietnamese art as well as a small contemporary exhibit. We found that the pieces were in various conditions from those that were exquisite to some which were showing signs of wear. There are extensive examples of sculpture, lacquer work, and silk painting. Our favorite exhibit were the thought provoking paintings by the contemporary artists. Note that the air conditioning was inconsistent throughout the museum. There were very few people there when we visited, and relative to other museums this one is quite understated, but if you are interested in art put this on your to do list.

A museum with an open mind.. Everytime I'm in Ha Noi I visit this museum and often several times. Partly because of what they show, but also because of the people who work in the museum. During the years they did become friends and I always feel proud when they show me the new things they did develop, especiallt for children.

Wonderful Museum. The Museum of Fine Arts in Hanoi was well worth a visit. It is accessible and nicely divided into three stories. Fine Arts from the 11th - 19th century on the ground floor; Paintings and contemporary sculptures and Folk art on the first floor and silk, and oil paintings as well as a creative space for children on the third floor.The layout facilitated a calm and relaxing visit to this wonderful museum. I would highly recommend a visit, especially on a hot day, to this lovely museum. You will not be disappointed.

Walked from our Hotel. We walked to this museum from our hotel even though we were advised to get a taxi - we love to look around a city and it wasn't really that far - it was very hot though. It was worth the walk - I loved it - there are displays over 2 buildings. I always think you can get to know a country by it's art and this is very true here. A lot of Vietnam's history is reflected in the art. Some of the bronze sculptors are fantastic and I especially loved the ceramic displays.

The musee d'orsay of Hanoi!. Yes that's a gross exaggeration but there is a ton of impressionistic art here that is beautiful and captivating. And they have AC. The ceramics in the basement are skippable, the 2nd floor is the highlight.

Great experience. Both the building and the historical and cultural content Vietnam fascinates us the beauty and elegance. A beautiful museum to be visited by us Westerners in contact with the oriental culture.

A bit far, though interesting art. The best pieces are the lacquered work, traditional art form of Vietnam. The Buddhist wooden statues from the 1700s are also quite magnificent. I wasn't particularly interested in the art, and the descriptions of the pieces are lacking, but this is a good place for a stroll on a rainy day. There are three floors of exhibitions. Make sure you don't miss the wing at the back of the museum, behind the stairs. It's quite far from Old Town by foot. Fee is VND30000.
A Must Visit Stop in Hanoi. This museum is highly recommended for arts lovers. The 3-floor building houses hundreds of Vietnamese paints and sculptures. The contemporary section is my favorite.
Interesting. Good collection and some of the Vietnamese stuff is really worth looking at. A bit sombre at times, but that's not bad when escaping the sweltering heat.

Worth a visit. An interesting collection of artifacts and art. Most very well displayed and good translations. Some wonderful old pieces. It was interesting seeing the change in art styles and subjects from colonial to communist to more liberal periods today. A very large collection and one the city should be proud of. We didnt see everything as the heat/humidity and sore feet defeated us. If youve got time and are interested in society and art its worth a visit.

good place to explore in rainy day. This place is suitable for all ages. The museum is well-maintained and serene with a fine collection of art from throughout the centuries. We all enjoyed our afternoon there. Highly recommended!
comprehensive collection. great overview of vietnames art and well worth a visit. some rooms were cool and some were very hot. wish the gift shops would stock items which reflect the displays.

Oh my gosh. This was an outstanding museum. As I mentioned a bit ago in my comments re the Vietnamese Women's Museum, I wish I'd know that the way to walk thru the exhibits was from left to right (from old to new). But regardless, it was fabulous. And the gift shop had original art from many current artists as well as special representative pieces of Vietnamese art. FINE museum.
meaningful place to visit. We enjoyed this art museum. They have really beautiful art pieces and various types, from painting to sculptures. We would highly recommend seeing this museum!

Nice historical review of art in Vietnam. This is a good place to spend an hour or so exploring the art history of Vietnam.
I found the pre 20'th century the most interesting; the more recent exhibits are a little biased (understandably I guess).
All in all a worthwhile place to visit

Wonderful art in a cool setting on a sweltering day. With a heat index between 106-110 degrees, I designed a day to be inside. If you are looking for a cool, quiet, uncrowded spot to see wonderful art, this is the place. In the main galleries, there were only 5 other people and no one in the side wing where applied arts and ceramics are location. The museum shop sells are but they were so rude that I decided not to buy.

Worth the visit for all types!. You don't have to be an art enthusiast to enjoy the very diverse collection here. Items span the length of Vietnamese history, ranging from old relics to some impressive and striking full-sized Buddhas and monks, as well as plenty of great paintings of both secular and political themes. A great selection of modern art rounds out the trip. Make sure to follow the signs to get your historical pathway right. Budget two hours.

Wonderful!. This museum was, for us, one of the highlights of our visit to Hanoi. There are some exquisite ancient sculptures, and a range of pieces from over the years right up into modern times. However, the section that most fascinated us is the large collection of enamel art. The Vietnamese have developed techniques for using this medium to create richly coloured paintings unlike anything we have seen in other countries. Well worth spending an hour or two here!

Fine Arts History. This is an interesting history of Fine Arts in Vietnam from early to modern times. A good mix of art and sculpture, together with some furniture, pottery and clothing. The collections are small but appear to be well curated. I would recommend visiting if you have the interest and time - when we were there some of the exhibits were off "travelling" so didn't see them all - and they were changing over exhibitions. The clothing/furniture exhibits from the ethnic minorities were really interesting.
If you've got the time. I wouldn't consider this a top priority of Hanoi sights but it's nice if you have the time. There are some interesting sculptures but the art left a bit to be desired.

For a change of pace. Pop in here after visiting the Temple of Literature for historic, modern and contemporary art. The carved wood doors and gates featuring scenes from everyday life was enchanting.

well worth a look for art and history lovers. Lovely place - particularly interesting was the ancient art, I found the newer contemporary works great but a bit repetitive in their subject. Best thing was we found a great bar in an old Art Deco mansion called Bar Better (Betta?) around the corner - good priced drinks (free beer wed and sunday!!) great rooftop
Preserving and presenting a glimps of Vietnams visual arts.. Provides the visitor with a comprehensive picture of the visual art works of Vietnam. Includes a couple of little gift shops.
