Art and History in style. Well laid out in an impressive French Colonial building, the Fine Arts Museum houses a spectacular and thorough display of Vietnam's rich artistic history from ancient times until now. A must see for anyone interested in history or any form of art.

Historically yours !. The Fine Arts Museum in Hanoi is a chronicle of the history of Vietnam narrated through its art . More than the paintings of the Modern period , I preferred the antiquities on the ground floor .If you are a history buff , you will probably enjoy the exhibits here . The paintings on exhibit are technically outstanding but I'd love to see a section where the contemporary artists take off from where the modernists left .

A bit of Everything .... Not massive art fans but daughter is so we went. Really enjoyed the wide variety from ancient to modern; stone carvings to lacquered-wood statues and the 'ugly' Buddhist monk figures with odd shapes and faces. Nice cool place to spend some time.
Awesome museum. This was a great ,useful to visit to get an understand of what fine art means im Vietnam. We saw some really beautiful pieces.

Well set out Museum with excellent examples of artworks over the centuries.. The Fine Arts Museum is a wonderful old building housing a wide range of paintings, drawings and sculptures , ancient and contemporary. It is well set out and you follow the history of art in Vietnam as you progress through the galleries on 3 floor levels. The gallery is also a quiet, peaceful and cool spot to visit, to take a breather from the busy world outside. The early works are vary from large sculptures and bas reliefs, to small artefacts. Then you progress through the gorgeous display of lacquer artworks. There is also an excellent section of artwork depicting the struggle for independence. My favourite section was the contemporary artwork. You can view excellent works which show French influence from the impressionist period. There are also works which show surrealist and abstractionist influences. The contemporary artworks of the 21 st century are varied . There are some excellent photo realism paintings and some wonderful works depicting modern Hanoi. The gift shop also has some great signed and numbered linocut and wood block prints for sale, by young Vietnamese artists at very reasonable prices. Thoroughly enjoyed this Museum. Definitely recommend a visit.

Great overview of Fine Arts. Lovely old building displays an excellent collection which draws from centuries of art including ancient sculptures, silk and lacquer painting, ceramics as well as modern works.
Great works of Art. I spent 2 hours here just in awe. Three Levels of great art over history. Each floor was unique and took you through a journey in vietnamese art through time.

Surprising treasures; good variety. We were pleasantly surprised at the extensive nature of the collections and how well things were labeled. A great glimpse into Vietnam culture and history, especially if you are a visual person. There are some incredibly unique pieces well worth seeing. A few things were the thousand armed boddhisatva statue, the lacquered statues from late 1700s, war-themed paintings from 40s to 70s. Museum is located right next to the Temple of Literature; it's definitely worth going while you are there. Entrance cost less than 2 dollars. There are few visitors so it's like having a museum to yourself. Will probably go back again when in Hanoi.

Outstanding cultural facility. Visiting the Vietnam Fine Arts Museum - just across the road from where we were yesterday - The Temple of Literature and National University - seemed like a good idea. Reflecting on the antiquity of some of the collection is sobering - a thousand and more years old. We will return as we only covered about a third of the collection in this extensive 1930s, French-built facility. The French outstayed their welcome but certainly left behind them some fine architecture.Employing media from carving and sculpture, through bronze, stone and lacquered wood to more modern materials of silk and oil painting - drawn from the French though adhering to Vietnamese and Cham expressions and styles - the collection covers influences from the early Confucian up to and beyond the Communist, patriotic depictions of the 1930s to the 1970s.Modern Westerners like us, imbued with Greek, Roman and European media and styles, will be inspired. Linking Vietnamese art to those periods viewers will see immediately the developments in thought and philosophy were often in advance of our own. Thanks Confucious and the early emperors of Vietnam.The English labels were occasionally amusing and often bemusing. I would love to get my editor's hands on them - with no disrespect. We will be going back quite soon.
Great, well worth checking out. We loved this Museum, it had a wide range of art across all periods. I was very impressed by the art collection and the quality of the art.
Quite good. Was not expecting to see replicas in a museum but overall it was interesting and isn't so large that it is daunting.

Don't miss this great art museum! A fantastic and fascinating introduction to art in Vietnam. My friends and I visited this museum after a visit to the Temple of Literature. We only had about an hour and a half, so we didn't get to see the side wing or the temporary exhibition of watercolors. Like the other reviewers, I had never really considered fine art in Vietnam before, and was truly fascinated by the museum as an introduction. It was well curated and presented. I only regret that we didn't have enough time to see/consider all of it, though I ran back on my last morning to buy a book from their small bookstore.
Very small but interesting. Contains artefacts from the stone age to modern times in just three rooms. But its the post 1945 art thyat s definately worth seeing both for its craftmanship and content.

Worth a visit !. The museum has a main fine arts building and a wing for more traditional arts and a room of temporary contemporary exhibits. . One floor of the fine arts building has the art organized by era, and the other by medium, i.e. silk painting, lacquer painting, oils, etc. There are many pieces which deal with subjects from the Vietnam (American) war, some absolutely beautiful, others very powerful statements. Some sculpture and ceramics though that is not the main focus. There is a nice museum gift shop. The café in the courtyard did not appear to be open. It is worth a visit if you have time or are interested in how the war was illustrated through fine art. Fee is minimal

blew my mind. I just never considered Vietnamese fine art. Aside from actual antiquities on the first floor which were very cool, there were lots of paintings from around 1940s to 1990s which while they had obvious French influence were also wildly original and that includes materials and techniques. I had never seen lacquer paintings. There was also a melding of traditional and modern style which is hard to describe. A small amount of straight up impressionist stuff which matched any westerners. I was enthralled. It matched my entire impression of the country as a place of originality and industriousness.

Fine art-fine building. There is some superb art in this museum.The paintings are well worth the visit, as is the sculpture.There is so much tourist 'tat' in the shops, badly done paintings, but the quality of the work here is superb.The day I went was also very quiet, far from the madding crowd!The buildings don't appear to have air conditioning or any sort of climate control.The American ambassador should take steps to to rectify this immediately, to preserve these beautiful works for future generations to enjoy.
uninspiring. This museum, while the artwork was amazing - everything is dark and there is not enough signage to help you get around. We left after just 15 minutes quite unimpressed.
Well worth a visit. We visited the Fine Arts Museum in Hanoi and were quite impressed with the displays. Well worth a visit.

Some Good, Some Average. My husband and I went to this museum last weekend. There are extensive exhibit spaces, but the "path" through the maze is not well marked, and the staff don't speak enough English to help guide you. There are some beautiful carvings and relief art. My husband and I especially enjoyed the ceramics exhibit which displayed several hundred years of vases and tea pots, and explaining the defining decorative characteristics of each dynasty.

Fine Arts Museum. Massive building, full of art. Some of the artwork is in a different building and would be easy to miss, so watch out for that. Good selection of art although a limited amount of contemporary pieces. The museum shop is not great - no prices and the quality of some of the items didn't seem very good.

Best museum. This is the best museum in Hanoi. They are two buildings, the first building is for Ceramic and clothes and the second one in about paintings, drawings, and sculpture. Interesting and good place to take picture. Not many people venture to the second building because they do not know how to access it. Look for the door close to the souvenirs shop and go downstairs to start.

Comprehensive and fascinating displays. Especially impressed with the wood carvings showing ordinary people fishing, playing musical instruments, laughing. I learned a lot of history.The contemporary art exhibit showed an understandable shift from figurative art to political art in the 1930s. Very moving.

Old style museum.. We chose to visit this museum because it is close to Literature temple. Displays are on two nice colonial buildings. Unfortunately the collections are exhibited in a casual way, without considering light, dust, and other crucial factor. Most important, the museum is poorly serviced by the staff, and you might touch statues and paintings without any problem (guides tend to do it while explaining to groups...!)

Some lovely pieces. We didn't have much time at the Museum, so concentrated on the third floor galleries with twentieth century Vietnamese paintings and drawings. Some of these were lovely - highly skilled pieces presenting a fascinating insight in to Vietnamese life. Some pieces were related to the struggles of the Vietnamese people during a series of wars, but others showed a much more domestic picture. We were very favourably impressed and wished that we had more time available.

Quiet and quite nice. There are some statues to look at, some paintings to gaze at, and so on. The usual for an art museum. It's not very large, and there are some pretty works, but unless you're an art enthusiast, I would recommend not going.

Definitely Worth A Visit. The museum is arranged chronologically, which means the first exhibit is more like archeology than fine arts. Which is fine: the selections are interesting throughout. You follow the arrows, which are clearly marked, to different galleries. Each gallery has an introduction in Vietnamese, English and French that is well-written and informative. Each piece of art is also labelled in English, which is very helpful. Many pieces of fine art from the 1930's, when French influence was strong, is truly beautiful but, alas, in need of conservation. Some paintings are fading, or the paint is flaking off. But the art shines through. Vietnam had been at war from 1945 through the 1970's, first with the French and then the Americans. So, much of the art is nationalistic in tone, some of it heavy handed, other pieces technically very good. The painting atop of this category is Hanoi Youth preparing to meet the American aggressors." Ok, but it's their reality. There are also very abstract and modern images, the further removed from war, the more human-centered the art.

hard to get to but worth it. We took a cab from the old quarter because the city (like every other cosmopolitan area of Vietnam) is not particularly walkable for longer distances. When we got there, surprised at the quality and scope of works. They have very ancient stonework/masonry and wood work from centuries ago to more modern/present-day artist. Empty except for a few expats like ourselves, which was actually nice to enjoy everything in peace but also a little sad the Vietnamese don't visit themselves. definlety some real gem of paintings there. There were 3 or 4 rooms with a lot of propaganda-insured work that were not tiresome but otherwise plenty of other interesting things to see. The museum was 3 or 4 levels, each with 4 rooms. There is a nominal price for admission.

A surprise. It isn't Musee D'orsay nor the Guggenheim but is was very enjoyable and worth a visit. It is not expensive and there were many pieces of art that were original in concept and execution and were also enjoyable. As well there were obvious pieces that reflected some well known art such as the piece "Sunflowers" by Van Gogh. I was not sure if this was deliberate or a send up. If you like art and wish to see local talent both ancient and modern please take the time as it will be well spent but don't expect the wow factor that you will get in European or most western galleries when you are suddenly confronted by well known Expressionists art.

A beautiful collection . If you love art this is worth some time. There are some truly exquisite pieces of art here. And it offers a perspective on the Vietnamese people, their history and their formative experience. If you like art this is worth some time. If you're not into art, you'll be bored.

Well worth a visit. As with the Fine Arts museum in HCM city this is a rewarding experience. Quite diverse but my highlight were the lacquer paintings which took me by surprise with their quality, depth and warmth.

Really well done, a Hanoi highlight. I'm not an art or museum buff, but I really enjoyed this museum. I spent about 2 hours wandering through the displays which is longer than I would typically spend at a museum. There's a great mix of arts from across the eras, including some really impressive modern Vietnamese art. The giant (maybe 2 metre tall) Buddhist monks and the goddess with many arms were highlights. It's the type of museum where you can just wander and stop and read about the things that catch your eye. You don't have to concentrate too hard or worry about the narrative, just enjoy the really impressive artworks.

A relaxing location for photography.. My initial expectation was that this is another museum since the original was badly damaged during the war. This location contracted expectation as the restored buildings and locale was used by locals as a photographic backdrop. Excellent floral decor was groomed in its respective places.This place is suitable for all ages.
Excellent. Well worth a visit. As artists, my partner and I thoroughly enjoyed this art museum. Very well kept, varied, interesting and original styles. Fantastic.

Definitely worth a visit. The museum is well-maintained and serene (somehow, despite the blaring horns outside), with a fine collection of art from throughout the centuries. The older works and the silk paintings are not to be missed, and save some time and energy for the extensive collections in the second building. You won't find everything to your liking, but it's a great place to wander and pause as you see fit.

Very enjoyable. This Museum is very well kept, clean and very nice presentation. I have to say that it is a bit difficult to find your way round so better signage or numbering of rooms would be very helpful. Having said this the artwork on show is just stunning. The layout also great and it is kept very clean. We came in the morning and it was not busy so plenty of time to enjoy the artwork in peace. Highly recommend a visit to this museum and you need 2 to 3 hours.

Brilliant.. Very well run. Great sellection of historical objects including sculptures, ceramics, ethnic items as well as great collection of ancient and modern art. Unlike some museums this one is well laid out it is clean and obviously cared for. A great place to see ancient Chinese, Hindu and other relics. This place helped to complete the picture of Vietnam for me. There is a great sellection of lacquer paintings as well as some very nice silk paintings. Great place. Much more than museum, much more than a gallery.

Art from all ages. My only criticism is that a) rooms could be numbered because you can get confused on where you've been & what's next, and b) it would make sense for the layout to have you do all the ancient stuff first so you get a sense of progression. That aside, if you like looking at beautiful things then this is a visual feast in particular for seeing how a regional art form like lacquer gets adapted to more modern subjects and how styles bridge continents, when you see echoes of Van Gogh or perhaps what inspired the Dutch master. A truly enjoyable afternoon spent out of the chill, mist & drizzle.

Sad to see the on grounds restaurantis closed. Very well set out museum with fantastic collection of historically important art works. I used to love coming here wander around the gallery for a couple of hours then having lunch in the on grounds restaurant sadly now closed down i hope it reopens soon!!

Nice collection of Vietnamese artwork, from ancient to modern. The Fine Arts Museum is well worth a visit, to view their excellent collection of artwork that spans much of the history of Viet Nam... Three floors with many rooms featuring works done in a variety of media (stone, wood, bronze, silk, oils, etc.) were enjoyable to view, all housed in a well-preserved building (French architecture). There is also a nice gift shop/bookstore off to the side, where you can purchase a book that covers the exhibits for 50K vnd. All in all, a nice spot to spend a couple of hours in Ha Noi and to learn more about the heritage and culture of Viet Nam -- enjoy :))
View of Viet Nam in art. the most interesting in this museum is understanding about Viet Nam's china. Besides, the art from the ancient time is also a great picture with bronze Drum.

Bit boring and just a few really good pieces. We were disappointed after our visit. The museum has a few levels but all in all we didn't saw many artpieces that we found really interesting, well made or intriguing. There isn't much, mostly non at all, information accompanied with the pieces but that seems to be the standard in the Asian museums. Also in comparison with the modern arts museum in Ho Chi Minh this wasn't one we would go back to or recommand.

Surprisingly excellent. An oasis of tranquility opposite the hectic temple of literature. Beautiful artifacts on the first floor, but more interesting 20th century paintings on the second. Currently hosting a beautiful exhibit of propaganda posters small entrance fee and well worth it.

An artists buffet of delights. Wonderful selection of art. Especially of interest the works from around the time of the war with America. Wonderful ancient examples of the culture also. Cheap entry. Quiet and just near the temple of literature so well worth locating.

Hanoi late 20th century artists on show. As well as late 20th century art and some modern artists from 40s thought 80s they have sculptures and ceramics from 11th century. Normally they will have a guest artist on show for extended period in one of the wings. Old colonial building is very interesting and the ceramic exhibition is down in the basement. I felt this building would make a fantastic hotel but suits use as museum.

awsome!!!. The Vietnam Fine Arts Museum, a museum in the system of Vietnam's national museums, is considered as a museum that occupies the most important position in maintaining and promoting the treasures of Vietnamese cultural and artistic heritage. Visiting the Museum i can understand the entire history of Vietnamese fine arts through the collections and exhibitions on display. The presentation of our permanent collections of important works of Vietnamese art offer the public unique insights into the culture and history of the Vietnam's ethnic communities.

Even made return visit!. Fabulous combination of museum and fine art gallery, a thorough emersion in Vietnamese material and visual culture. Initial visit with a group wasn't enough, so returned for a more leisurely perusal. Would go back a third time if ever in Hanoi!
Amazing. I could have spent many more hours there Bought some beautiful art works and I was amazed at the range of artworks on display Stunning work

Nice, small museum - No contemporary art. Although the museum is small, what they have is generally good. Everything in the collection, plus a lot more can be seen in the histroy museum, so it really isn't worth the extra trip!

Time well spent. There are 2 buildings on the property of this museum. Don't spend too much time in the first one (as you enter, on your left). The second building hosts a far more appealing and significant collection of local paintings and statues.

Average. I visit fine art museums wherever I go, but the art museums in Vietnam (Hanoi and HMC) are not overwhelming, the exhibitions could be presented better. It is still worth a visit, as locetd in a colonial building and you get an overview about art troughout the centuries.
Not Impressive. It has some nice pieces, but overall there is nothing truly magnificent about the works here, most of which come from around 1960.

Its Art. I'm not overly interested in Art, but for a dollar AUSD entry we thought we would check it out. The art is amazing and some of the techniques used are way beyond anything I've seen in any other museum

From old to current art. We enjoyed this art museum. The ground floor starts off with Vietnams pre history. The first objects you are looking at are bronze and stone artefacts. The giant Buddhas and Gods are amazing. As you move through to the second and third floors, you are viewing oil paintings and Lino prints. These contemporary works give insight into the recent past as well as the traditional lifestyle of the people of Vietnam. Spend some time here if you love art museums. The bookstore was also a lovely place to visit and see contemporary artists work for sale.

Good place to see something interesting. Very well-known in Hanoi and attractive with variuos of arts for us to see.It was good experience for us because we got all information from our tour guide.High recommendation for this place.

An outstanding collection which is not to be missed!. I confess that I do like museums. So spending nearly three hours here may seem excessive to some but there is just SO much to see! The museum is located at the far end of The Temple of Literature, which attracts lots of visitors. So I am not sure why we were two of perhaps only a dozen visitors.The entrance fee is just 30,000 dong - a little under £1. There is a room with lockers to leave bags. Sadly, there is no floor plan and no brochure was given to us which could lead you to the museum's highlights. But there are so many!Although billed as a fine arts museum, it actually embraces the decorative and applied arts, too. The displays are very well signed, with an explanation to each room. The curators have tried to take the visitor through a history of Vietnam in chronological order (which is why the floor plan would have been helpful as we sometimes went out of sequence). There is a collection of prehistoric artefacts, an amazing collection of carvings from over 1000 years ago, textiles, ceramics and paintings in a variety of formats and styles, eg on silk to contemporary art. So for those from London, it is like a mini Tate, National Gallery, V&A and British Museum rolled into one.There is a good quality art/book/gift shop, although it is hidden away for some reason. There were no catering facilities. The museum is over three floors and in two buildings. I did not see any lifts, so those with mobility issues may need to check access arrangements. Do go, though. You won't be disappointed!
Beautiful Art Pieces. They have really beautiful art pieces and various types, from painting to sculptures. Nice to spend the afternoon visiting the museum.
Lots of Art Regarding War. Very good depictions of life during wartime. Powerful sculptures. We would highly recommend seeing this museum!

Some interesting art.. Not a big art buff but do like a good piece of art. There were some really interesting pieces in here and descriptions in French and English. If you're really into art it's definitely worth a visit. Would have been made better by some further background information about the painters and art periods - there's a little but not much.

Enjoyable afternoon. Housed in two adjoining French colonial buildings. Large number of varying types of ceramics on the lower level of the left hand building. Graphic arts and applied arts on the second level. in the other building, I particularly liked the lacquered art as well as silk art. There are a large number of very well done middle 20th century paintings mainly portraying war themes. Also, many Buddhas and other statues. Definitely worth a visit.

Only for those who really love the arts. We found this museum rather tedious as the art work was not very appealing to us as Westerners. I generally enjoy art galleries but this one didn't appeal, it was dull and tedious.

Fantastic Art, Buddhas and Ceramics.. Really worth a visit. Great respite from the crazy streets of Hanoi. Also across the road from the Temple of Literature. Great quality displays which were a lot cleaner than 5 years ago. Gives you a great insight into Viet culture and history. Stunning Buddhas and interesting ceramics display. Nice shop too which is a little tucked away but worth checking out for good presents, cards etc.

Art n Art. If you enjoy arts, depending on many factors, you will definately enjoy or dislike this museum. At the time if my visit, nothing major was happening except for my encounter with an awesome Japanese artist promoting his art, plus it was rainy outside. Great experiene for me !

Some memorable surprises here. Whether you are into Art and Architecture or not, this site is a thoroughly enjoyable ornament in a delightful city. If you are staying near the Old Quarter it is within comfortable walking distance of the Hang Bong Road and the walk takes you through some of the most open and interesting areas of Hanoi. There are parks with beautiful gardens and some intriguing statues on the way to the Museum. If you get lost- highly unlikely - there are plenty of officials in a bewildering variety of uniforms only too pleased to help you find your destination. The art work includes reference to village life, traditional culture, revolutionary struggle and resistance to colonialism. There are surprising signs of influence by European painters such as Picasso and this helps to connect the Museum experience with the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum site's art exhibition. The larger than life sculptures are stunning and because you will encounter them early in your visit they set the tone for what is to come. The various rooms are often quite small and accessible by a broad staircase in this wonderful colonial style buidling.

Vietnam's Premiere Fine Arts Museum. This review is quite late. The Fine Arts Museum (Bao Tang My Thuat) in Hanoi is housed in a beautiful building with a typical Vietnamese architectural style. It is the premiere fine arts museum being larger than the Fine Arts Museum in Ho Chi Minh City. There are interesting art works delving into varied themes: war and defense, love for country, and martyrdom, among others. There is a small section displaying modern art from contemporary local artists. I was only able to take photos of the exterior building since photography inside the museum is forbidden.

Don't Miss This Gem!. The Fine Arts Museum in Hanoi is housed in a beautiful Colonial Style French building with outstanding art and exhibitions. It is beautifully curated with paintings and sculptures dating from the 11th century to the 21st century. It is laid out chronologically so the visitor understands the evolution of Vietnamese art and artists. We even found one painting by an artist who painting we bought 15 years ago! It requires at least 1.5 hrs. Truly a gem.

Shows the reality of communism. I love art - including this art- such a reflection of the time of the recent past- artist's continued to have a personal style and appease the powers in charge. It was (and really still is) always a risk to show truths in this area of the world- art transcends where it can.Do not look for a slick French/American set up but one very much worth seeing.

Traditonal and contemporary. Forget the fine art, this is a museum of some of the best art in Viet Nam, presented with care and aesthetically pleasing. A must if you want to explore art in all its forms from this part of the world.

Arts & Artits. If you enjoy arts, depending on many factors, you will definately enjoy or dislike this museum. At the time if my visit, nothing major was happening except for my encounter with an awesome Japanese artist promoting his art, plus it was rainy outside. Great experiene for me !

Probably the Best Collection of Vietnamese Art Anywhere. If you are expecting something akin to the Louvre or to see works by artists you know, you will be disappointed. But if you are interested in art and history as presented by artists, this museum is a must see. With an admission price of about a dollar and a half, there is no reason to miss this interesting and sometimes fascinating collection of Vietnamese art.

Great Vietnamese. Wonderful collection of all periods of Vietnamese art history. My favourites are the pieces of To Ngoc Van and Tran Van Can, also the works from the "communist" are very interesting. The museum (which is beautiful too) has a nice collection than the museum in Saigon. Worth visiting.
You will need a whole day here.. We spent the whole day here, my husband is an artist, and He was delighted for find such an amazing display

Interesting but tiresome. They have a great exhibition of ancient art, but a looooot of communist war propaganda!! I am not anti-communist or anything, but after a while you become fed up with all the heroic soldiers and brave peasants.... It was refreshing to see paintings of Vietnamese girls from ethnic minorities once in a while. Go and check it out - it is cheap and Vietnamese school children go there with their schools - so the images there are part of the world they grow up seeing, and therefore great to see.

Splendid. Wonderful collection of all periods of Vietnamese art history.My favourites are the pieces of To Ngoc Van and Tran Van Can, also the works from the "communist" are very interesting.The museum (which is beautiful too) has a nice collection than the museum in Saigon.Worth visiting. It is just behind the Van Mieu (Literature Temple).(When oh when do Vietnamese museums start with audio guides, like in European museums :) )

Nice collection in beautiful old building.. Enjoyed the architectural features of the building as much as the collection. Especially enjoyed the fine examples of lacquer paintings. Quiet and air conditioned. Perfect for hot afternoon. Very short cab ride from Hoan Kiem Lake. Admission charge for 2 adults less than $2.
Fine Arts. Better for showing history and culture than any museum in Ho Chi Minh City. Shows Hanoi as the cultural city of Vietnam. Wonderful French colonial architecture.
Superb. The art we saw was outstanding yet we were almost the only people in the Museum. Not the easiest place to find but well worth a visit.

Very worthwhile to visit. Housed in a French designed building, this museum is packed full of beautiful artwork from Vietnam's history from sculptures to silk paintings to oil works and wood paintings. There are lots of stairs so wear comfy shoes!

A must-see for ones who are interested in art. I used to visit this museum many times but still want to come back if having free time. The museum showcases a lot of Vietnam's cultural and artistic heritages which are arranged in chronological order.A visit to this museum will provide you an insight into Vietnamese history and understand Vietnamese spirit through different time, under talented hands and eyes of artists. With those who do not specialize in the arts, the museum is still a good place to see interesting things includes wide range of pictures, statues, sculpture, decorative art in temples, pagodas, tombs, houses and royal palaces. Remember to take your camera with full battery - you will feel like to take photos of so many beautiful artifacts there :)With a very little money for entrance fee, you can have a great time there I'm sure :)

Worthwhile. The facility is older, with confusing layout. Only some of it is air conditioned. But...the collection is really outstanding. From the historical and tribal artifacts to the beautiful lacquer paintings to the fascinating contemporary items, the museum was a wonderful surprise. Unfortunately, most Vietnam tours concentrate on historic, if not ancient sites, ignoring the contemporary efforts of a developing nation. My suggestion is to find some time for this gem.

Don't miss the temporary exhibition space. The lacquer and silk paintings are always a pleasure to visit here, but don't miss the new ceramics wing and especially the temporary exhibition space which often shows contemporary artists and can be visited for free.

History of art. A particularly interesting insight into to history of art and artists of Vietnam .Sculptures and Buddhas landscapes ,silk painting ,beautiful lacquer work.The artists paid by the state ,the art reflects the moods of the country from propaganda inspired pieces to modern sculpture.Great for a rainy day.

Unexpected treasures in Hanoi. Wasn't sure what to expect, but this was great and stood comparison with any art museum in the West (and for my money better than the equivalent in HCMC). Well displayed and labelled, good clear layout. Some excellent early sculpture. But the real highlights for me a room of remarkably realistic eighteenth-century lacquer Buddhist figures; lacquer paintings, something I'd not seen before; and some scorchingly powerful paintings of the revolution and war period. The shop somewhat bizarrely placed in the centre of the museum is well worth a visit.

Great art museum. We have been to some of the world's finest museums in Madrid and all over Italy and I can truly say that this museum was a pleasant surprise. We had no expectations and the art was of exceptional quality. I would recommend it to anyone that loves art.
Oke, but not a must. Ground floor is Buddhist history dating back centuries, the other floors are us Vietnam war art, nice but explicit sometimes.

Beautiful collection of Vietnamese arts. We spent a morning wandering about this Museum. There is a broad range of Vietnamese arts on display from ceramics, paintings, embroidered silk, furniture and sculptures. Some of the pieces on display are amazing. The museum is across the road from the Temple of Literature, also worth a visit.

first visit 2011. This museum is near the Temple of Literature and well worth a visit. There are some impressive Viet sculptures and many paintings and ceramic work by noted Viet artists. The museum has 3 floors and if I remember rightly, it's free. There is an interesting gift shop run by the wife of a famous Viet potter and she speaks English so can give you added interesting info.

Good place to start to delve into Vietnam traditional fine arts and modern art. I liked almost everything except some wrong translations in english and in french. Very quiet place given the disdain of locals for fine arts (during my 3 hours visit, I only 3 local visitors)

A solid afternoon out. I love art and we've visited many art exhibitions and museums on our travels, so my husband and I were looking forward to this.It's not too far to walk from old town, about 20 minutes. The entrance fee was 30K each, which was reasonable considering how much there is to see.We did enjoy it, but there are some criticisms - they don't provide a printed guide/map (even one sheet would be enough) to show you what each room contains. There is a map outside on a board, but this 1930s building has A LOT of rooms and at times was difficult to navigate - or, rather, it didn't have a good flow - and we were worried that we'd miss something.It's generally well lit (not all rooms) and some parts have air conditioning - after negotiating all those stairs it felt like a bit of a workout.The staff weren't unfriendly, but they weren't helpful either - some were doing each other's hair, and one was sleeping in the gallery! Nobody acknowledged us as we walked around, which was a shame. Might be nice if they had staff who could point you in the right direction/explain about the more important works.It took us around 2.5 hours to get round everything, but we were skipping things at the end - we almost felt like there were too many similar items on the walls.We wanted to stop at the adjoining café afterwards for lunch, around 13:00, but it looked closed and had no vibe at all so we went elsewhere (Moment café about 10 mins walk from museum, which was excellent). Overall a good way to spend a couple of hours, but not an enthralling experience.

Very well done!. Do not miss the amazing Vietnamese art here. The lacquer paintings are beautiful and unique and so are the silk paintings. The contemporary art is also very good and telling of the country;s history. This is an impressive collection and please do NOT overlook the ceramics in the lower most level!!!

Fine Arts Museum. A huge display of art housed in a lovely old building. Numerous rooms to get lost in. The sculptures were great. They ranged from ancient to modern. Many of the modern ones are war focused. The art work is very varied from ancient to modern and we thoroughly enjoyed the different mediums used. We have taken a large selection of photos of the various pieces on display

Not up to what I hoped, buit still good.. I was thrilled to see some of the art I had previously seen only in photos, especially the Impressionist and ethnic art. I was surprised that some of the “revolutionary” (propaganda) art was quite good. I cannot help but feel that Vietnam has even more to offer, but, I suppose that is in Saigon. I am also not all that knowledgeable about art. It was very easy to get to and leave via taxi.

The best visit in Hanoi. The museum is in a beautiful building and is packed with fascinating artefacts. Fine Nguyen dynasty sculpture and paintings, beautiful woodblock prints from the mountain peoples, and amazing contemporary works are all on display. I really enjoyed looking around, the art on display is breath taking.
good.. it was interesting to see, however a bit repetitive. although we are not arty people so others may enjoy it more.

An entire range of art under one roof, several floors, and great shop for purchases. When you get your ticket stamped, pick up a map. Situated in this old French colonial mansion with its wings, you will find art ranging from the early era of Vietnam's history, Cham art, religious art, an excellent display of ceramics and traditional tribal arts. There is a large selection of contemporary art. I would recommend reading up on the arts of Vietnam before coming to the gallery OR stopping in at the first gallery shop that sells original prints (approximately $200 much better than other galleries in the city), oils, some other items, and some excellent art books at incredible prices (about $25). Study them if you are interested and come back. You will not be sorry. It is a great place to learn about Vietnam and its art. The fee to get in is 30,000 dong. There is a nice little cafe on the property.

Difficult to find Fine Arts in this museum. One of my friends is an artist so she wanted to visit an Arts Museum. It's close to Van Mieu, a popular tourist attraction. Therefore instead of visiting an Art Gallery, we went to visit this museum after going to Van Mieu. The building outside looked okay. However, you couldn't find any good quality Arts exhibits there. The exhibition hall was old, not well maintained. The exhibits were crowded together. And the way they classified the exhibits were quite strange to me. I think this museum is once for a lifetime. That means, I should just visit it once in my lifetime, not again. It is not a loss if you go without it at all.

Fantastic. This museum is very well laid out with a great range of arts and crafts for all to enjoy. Of particular interest are the wonderful displays of clothing, utensils, crafts etc from the very diverse ethnic tribes of Vietnam. There's a lovely coffee shop on the grounds as well.

Mediocre Museum. This was a one block walk from the Temple of Literature, which we loved. The first floor has artifacts dating back 2000 years so that was interesting. The 2nd and 3rd floors had contemporary paintings and statues that we skimmed through, although we did pause to take pictures of the unique monks' statues on the 2nd floor. There was hardly anyone else there.

Interesting for lovers' painting. We just visited Fine Arts Museum to update our guide book to travelers. Interesting museum where you find paintings exhibited by themes: wars, reconstruction of Vietnam after wars, scenic landscapes in Vietnam etc...We Cosmos Travel Vietnam Co., Ltd believe that travelers loving painting and fine arts should visit this museum before looking at galleries in Hanoi or Saigon

Interesting art pieces. There are some interesting art pieces there including large sculptures of well known buddhist monks, however when it came to the paintings, it was slightly disappointing, not because of the subject which trended towards popular communist themes, but because the general execution of the pieces (and maintenance) seems to be of a lower standard than some of the galleries we visited nearby!

Notional but not world treasure. As one expects a lot of art works with propaganda flavour. However this doesn't mean that they are better or worse. Most of the works are quite similiar in the terms of style. A lot of painfull realism and not so many art-works that would fit into frames of other art movements.

A Great Tour Guide. Our tour guide Nguyen Duc Dien from Indo China tours was so informative, and an excellent guide. He looked after us so well and answered all our questions. We also visited the old Quarter, The Temple of Literature, Lake Of The Restored Sword and Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum which was closed because of celebrations for his birthday. We had been there in 2007, and saw him lying in state. Dien made sure we were checked onto our next flight before he left us.

Good place to keep dry or cool off. A short walk from the Temple Of Literature and worth it, particularly if the weather is wet or very humid. There's 3 floors of well displayed exhibits including some VERY good modern work. Could do with more seating so that you can rest and take in the bigger exhibits. There's a coffee shop in the grounds
Fine works displayed. A beautiful display of fine art works and artefacts, worth spending an afternoon to enjoy the pictures and sculptures.

Interesting perspectives on Vietnamese culture. The Museum has a good collection that provides a visitor to Vietnam with very interesting perspectives on the development of Vietnamese society and culture over many hundreds of years, although with greater emphasis on the last 100 years. The collection includes a range of art forms - paintings and prints, sculpture, ceramics, etc. It also has a large space devoted to temporary exhibitions, which was occupied by a quite lovely collection of recent paintings on the day of our visit. There is a very small entry fee. The gift/souvenir shop is a good one. Worth a visit even if you are not an art buff.

Some excellent art works. I went to this museum twice, it was far bigger than I expected. There is a mix of war-type art and contemporary, both enjoyable though overall I preferred the contemporary. If you like seeing a mix of different work by various artists, you can find this here. Recommended.I bought a couple of pendants from the gift shop, 60,000 VND, attractive, small gifts.

Wonderful variety of art. Perhaps the most absorbing few hours I have spent in any museum. I loved the variety of this place, with so many different styles and materials on display, covering ancient to modern periods.There is a lot to see, and if you don't follow the numerical sequence of rooms (as shown on the printed guide you pick up on entry), it would be easy to miss some interesting exhibits.Some exhibits are amusing, some very moving, some thought-provoking, and some simply stunning in their content/beauty. My particular favorites were The 1,000 Eye and 1,000 Arm Guan Yin, Four Smiles, the lacquered Buddhanandi, Playing as Little Soldiers, Uncle Ho Plays with Children, the bronze Commemoration, the oil Central Vietnam, and the one with the tag "When you are eating the fruit, think of the person who planted the tree".A fine must-visit museum, housed in a beautiful French Colonial building.

Bronze and lacquer sculptures. Some war bronzes were strong and patriotic. They were the originals of those in museums in the south. Anyone who likes Buddha sculptures will be impressed by the fine lacquer work and the realistic faces on the Buddha images. Excellent lacquer paintings and silk paintings filled two large rooms. Definitely worth the time to see and think about the art Vietnam has produced.

Vietnam's Best Art Museum. Hanoi's Fine Arts Museum is likely the country's best museum to see Vietnamese art: both centuries old religious sculptures, textiles, and art, to rotating contemporary exhibits. Housed in a beautifully restored French colonial building, you could easily spend over two hours here (art buffs, that is). Navigating the museum is easy -- signs guide you through the exhibits. One building is dedicated to ceramic, pottery, and metalwork, while the main building has ancient to contemporary works of art. Each room has a plaque that describes the era and type of work -- you know what you're looking at in this museum.Personally, I found the pieces from the past century the most impressive. They detail Vietnam's past, its daily life, victories, tragedies, and everything in between. Entrance is 40,000VND, and you're free to take pictures throughout the museum. You can't bring bags in however: purses and backpacks are placed in lockers near the entrance.
Beautiful art pieces. Loved this beautiful museum with its wonderful pieces. The building is worth seeing itself. It's interesting to see the history of the country. Be warned that is is very warm.
Overview of Vietnamese Art. Good overview on evolution of visual arts (mostly paintings) in Vietnam. Nice visit for those inclined.

Intersting place. I'm basically interested in art museum. This museum secretly shows the history of Vietnam. Almost half of the pictures demonstrated the lifes during the Wars, women and childrens' life, men's life and the connection between soilder and people..Other pictures show Vietnamese daily life in past, cultures, religiousbut those were described in Veitnam, not English. Just only the name written in English, vietnamese , and FrenchThe staffs there rarely speak english.i spend about 3 hrs there. There was a small coffee shop near by. It's very nice ;)

Pleasantly surprised..... After many trips to Hanoi I eventually visited the Fine Arts Museum. Perhaps it was my disappointment in the Art Museum in HCMC that led me to ignore it for so long. I was pleasantly surprised. The ground floor contains the oldest works of stone and bronze and wood, and works from Ly and Tran Dynasty periods. with some being replicas. There are some fine lacquered wooden statues of royalty. The quality of the more modern art on the upper floors is mixed but nonetheless interesting. The adoption of Western painting styles is evident but so is the persistence of Vietnamese techniques and motifs. There are some beautiful, intricate, etched lacquer works. Scattered through the galleries is some very nice bronze sculptures.A separate wing houses applied and decorative art works. Best of this is a newly refurbished ceramics gallery in the basement. It is definitely worth a visit, maybe after the Temple of Literature. It was not crowded, photography is allowed and there is a nice coffee shop to relax at afterwards,
Worth a visit. Very nice art work from Vietnamese artists from different generation. Have some historical items in this museum as well.

Outstanding world class museum. We were blown away with the depth and quality of art in this museum. Housed in a stunning building, allow at least 3 hours to fully appreciate the works. Of particular note is the extensive collection of Vietnam war art, amongst the most moving I have seen.Just go. You are sure to find something of interest.
Good look at Vietnamese art. It's a good exposure to Vietnamese art. I learned about lacquered wood and etched lacquer. This developed because of the materials that are available locally.
Not a bad little museum. This museum shows off the pride of Vietnamese Fine Arts. You need to take it for what it is. There are some pieces that definitely made me pause and admire.
great. if you have read my review in bangkok, you will realise that i like art and music. this is also my favourite place.

Definitely worth a visit if you enjoy art. We went to visit this museum on one of our first days in Hanoi and were pleasantly surprised by the beautiful displays. We especially enjoyed the Vietnamese art from the 20th century as well as the room filled with statues of famous monks (lacquered wood). The part of the museum with the applied arts and ceramics were less interesting. All in all, a very nice museum for a place that is rather unassuming from the outside.

If this is the best that Vietnam's artists can produce, I am sorry.. I am an avid art lover, and I was so excited for this portion of our itinerary in Hanoi. However, I came out of the museum in a slump because I had been so disappointed by the exhibitions. I hope that the collections will become more varied in style and age in the future.
Excellent museum which shouldn't be missed. Many wonderful paintings -- oil, watercolor, silk along with beautiful sculptures (many bronze) throughout the museum. Stroll at your leisure to enjoy.

Worth a visit. It is not the greatest art museum in the world, far from it, but it is good to acquaint yourself with local art. Due to the country's recent history expect to see war themes predominate but do visit even if you don't like the subject.

Interesting insight into Vietnamese art. I learned a lot about lacquer painting here and hadn't realised it was still so popular. A traditional technique has been adapted to western iconography from Impressionism to social realism. Interesting

some good and some bad. The museum is close to the Temple of Literature so worth visiting at the same time. The ground floor galleries and the separate gallery (joining building - to find it you need to follow the "exi-museum shop signs that will take you through it) are the most interesting, the first floor of the main building is a bit of a let down with fairly modern paintings which I personally did not particularly appreciate, the quality is nowhere close to the value fo the antiquities shown downstairs

Different. Is housed in a colonial building. The artworks are all Vietnamese. The first floor has a large number of ancient sculptures of great quality. The other floors have mostly paintings. Many, understandably have the theme of war in Vietnam and the government of Ho Chi Min. In fact there are pictures of great quality as well as some sculptures. I really liked

Good craft and very average art. The collection of art could be reacher, and the explanations contain less of factual errors and lacks. I enjoyed visiting the crafts collections though. The ceramics room was closed.

Worth a visit to see North Vietnam artist perspective. A short stroll from the Temple of Literature, we truly enjoyed our visit to this repository for a small range of interesting art and artifacts housed in a former colonial residence. Room after room are filled with Vietnamese treasures from the bronze-age right up to the contemporary, with an especially rewarding series of lacquer paintings detailing the Vietnam War from a North Vietnamese perspective. The work is not in any kind of climate-controlled environment, so we are glad we went when the weather was cool. Some definite hits like the 1000 eye and arm Quan Lin statue, some excellent Champa era sculpture, and the delicate paintings of Than Van Can and exquisite lacquer paintings of Nguyen Van Binh

Inspiering. Really beautiful, espacialy for western art lovers it really nice to see all art styles you know but than with a vietnamies touch to it. It's a great place to forget about busy hanoi for a while and enyoj art.

Loved this place. We spent a couple of ours here. I really loved all of the artwork here. Many lovely Buddhist statues, lots of old artefacts and some interesting paintings. The building it is housed in is a really lovely old French Colonial building. There is also a lovely café in the grounds were we enjoyed a lovely lunch.
Larger than I thought it would be. This museum is quite large and has a good variety of works to see. You need at least an hour and a half to go through the museum.

Well worth a visit. This is something a bit different from the focus elsewhere in Hanoi. It gives a great insight into a lot of Vietnamese history with some very good exhibits.An oasis of tranquility if you feel the need to get away from the hubbub of the main tourist attractions.
Beautiful Building. Loved the building the museum was housed in. Lots to see here with a great range of ancient statues and many contemporary pieces as well.

Good overview of Vietnam's fine arts tradition. The museum contains a few prehistoric pieces and some Buddhist statuary of note. Bit it focuses primarily on 20th century art that resulted after the establishment of the first fine arts school under French colonialism. There are many gorgeous lacquer paintings and paintings on silk, very much in a Vietnamese style. The topics of the modern pieces are village life or the fight for independence; there is next to no abstraction or unique innovation in the works, but the museum does a good job in presenting its holdings.

Nice art. The museum is located quite near to the temple of literature and some nice restaurants so you can make a nice day of it in this part of Hanoi. The museum features ancient as well as modern Vietnamese art and it's quite a treat to see the two! I particularly enjoyed the modern paintings, depicting the war and daily life in Vietnam. The paintings are not abstract, they all tell an obvious story and I find that refreshing in 20th century art. It's just $1 entry, so go have a wander for a few hours!

LOCAL art history...worth the time to realize the context and content. We usually avoid anything called "fine arts" but this was worth the visit because it was truly Vietnamese. It was fascinating to see how the usual European vogues were translated -- more or less successfully -- into the local context. There is a LOT here, because the good collection of the historic carvings and statues to rooms and rooms of painting, silk painting, lacquer works etc. Yes, some of the standard revolutionary approaches and hymns to independence, but that's what the country is about and it is important to recognize the passion behind the positions. Not strong on explanation, but just amble and ramble and you will absorb a lot. Bracket it with the ethnography/history museums and a visit to contemporary galleries (such as Suzanne Lecht) and you will have a good grasp of the artistic whole.
story tellers. the museum to me told a story of the struggles that the vietnamese people have been through from colonialism, revolution, war. What a resilient people

Museum with beautiful paintings. Visitors find some beautiful original painting in this museum. It is in Old Quarter not very far from the Temple of Literature and walking distance from most of the hotels. This is a very interesting place for the lovers of Vietnamese paintings and for those keen to know about Vietnam and its people. A good place to spend a couple of hours.

Impressive. We were in the main building and saw arts from ancient time up to today. The paintings were the most interesting and it was a lot of history in them. It was also many beautiful silk paintings.

Small and limited selection. Unfortunately this lovely building had some historical works but not many contemporary art.The gift shops offered some original works and yet, nothing of young/up and coming artists.The neighborhood is filled with various galleries and art shops with bright and beautiful selections.For the low admission price, it was ok, but it could use more splashes of bright and bold colors one sees in some the Vietnamese celebrations.

Fascinating insight into culutral adaptation. The works from the twentieth century have a very strong influence of French modernist styles. Clearly viewable a implicit and explicit styling of Impressionism, Cubism, Fauves, Van Gogh, Gauguin, et al.But each work was transformed subtly (and not so subtly) by Asian aesthetics , content and media (such and lacquer painting).An absolute must for students of art history.

Spent the whole day. We loved this museum. Spent the hold day exploring it from to to almost bottom. Start on top floor and work down to see water colors, lacquers, silk paintings and oils reflecting Vietnam culture and past through art. I really enjoyed it. At the end we discovered the wing where we were pretty much alone. One floor was all adornment from hill cultures - clothes, weaving a baskets and more. Then we discovered to our delight that they were setting up for a show of contemporary artists and we were invited in. What an opportunity; met some of them too. From Malaysia, America, Vietnam, and maybe someplace else. Great show. We breezed through the ancient stuff having finally run out of steam. Took a break midway at their cafe - the matchbox. Highly recommend the black sticky rice with yogurt. Yum!

If you are art lovers. Not a big one (comparing to European museums) , but worth visiting to get to know contemporary (mainly 20th century) Vietnamese artists. Great gift shop (prints, posters, books etc)
Some modern and history. Worth a stop to see the modern art. bit of a focus on the conflicts that they had. Well laid out and a nice café on the grounds

First floor is the best. There are some very nice examples of ancient Vietnamese sculpture on the first floor, but you can work very quickly through the newer stuff on the second and third floors without missing value. There is also a very nice café on the grounds.

There was no one here!!. A short walk or cyclo trip from the inner city will bring to the museum of fine art. The museum is a three story building which houses, in chronological order - first floor to third floor - , fine Vietnamese art. It is worth a visit if you are interested in the art of Vietnam.

Noteworthy.. Allow plenty of time to walk through this wonderful museum with its extensive collection of Vietnamese art from ancient times through modern times. Beautiful galleries with helpful curatorial notes. Many of the war era paintings displayed beauty and originality, suggesting a tolerance and appreciation of artistic expression.

For art lovers. The museum is spread over a number of floors with a souvenir shop that is well stocked and reasonably priced. The bronze sculptures were among my favourites. Art works from centuries ago are showing their age but interesting nonetheless.

Great Museum. This museum covers Cambodian art over the last 1500 years, with an emphasis on the Angkor Wat and 20th century periods. It also features the best gift shop I have ever seen in a museum. Lots of original art (from small prints to large oil paintings) along with the typical souvenirs and trinkets.

Learn a little about Vietnamese Art. I spent a few hours at the museum. Lots of interesting paintings reflecting upon Vietnamese history and culture. Many of the paintings heavily influenced by French artistic movements. On the grounds are a number of large sculptures, some of which are quite good.

Pleasantly surprised. The museum is a pleasant way to spend a few hours. It is small but well-curated, and housed in a lovely old building. There are clean bathrooms on most (if not every) floor, a decent cafe and 2 souvenir shops, one of which has a nice selection of original artwork.
Worth a trip. Has a great range of art and offers a different perspective on life in Vietnam, it worth a 2 hour visit and won't take you more
Great Art. Brilliant art in fantastic quiet colonial building. Beautiful sculptures and very moving work representing the war. Peace and quiet in the midst of chaos. A must for any art lover.

Well worth a visit. A museum well worth visiting when you're in Vietnam. As well as taking in more traditional art forms, the Fine Arts Museum also has a well-presented selection of later, and post cultural reformation art and sculpture. The museum is well laid out and curated with clear, multi-lingual signage throughout.
Beautiful!. I thought this was one of the best museums in the area! Very clean and well laid out. Signs were in English so I was able to understand what I was looking at. Beautiful museum.

Okay but.... This museum has some beautiful pieces in it especially in there lacquer collection (and toilets everywhere!)The real disappointment is the lack of much information for foreign visitors. Just some basic very dated placards introducing each room. A shame as I really wanted to know extra detail and would have got much more out of my visit if it were there.

great art. We love fine arts and this museum/art gallery is fanatic I would recommend to all art lovers. Spread over 3 or 4 floors there is plenty to view. I really liked the war images. There were interesting sculptures and very good use of lighting.

Always Interesting. This was my 4th visit to Hanoi in 7 years and each time I have visited this Museum. It's in a rambling old French villa and has lots of fine exhibits. The museum shop which is a little hard to find is well worth looking for/buying at. At $1 (20KDong) this is a bargain and being very close to Craftlink, KOTO and the Temple of Literature all in Van Mieu makes a lovely day out.
Surprising museum. Quite a surprise to find such a good fine arts museum. Well worth a visit, and close to the Opera House.

Second half was much better (in my opinion). I loved the second part of the gallery with the painting and carvings made from different materials. It was unique and the gallery was in an attractive building. The first part didn't really interest me, more contemporary.Is it worth a visit?.... Yes, but not if time is limited.

Great Art Museum. A very comprehensive collection of Vietnamese art, from ancient to present times. Many different media are represented - painting, sculpture, posters, etc. The Fine Arts Museum is across from Van Mieu (Temple of Literature) and the two can be combined, although that would make for a tiring day. Or, save this for an impossibly hot or rainy day. If you're visiting in the summer you'll have your pick of both!

must-see if you're in Hanoi and you love art. I really enjoyed visiting this museum. There was so much amazing art in there across the entire span of Vietnam's history. I was really impressed, not only by how gorgeous much of the art was, but also how unusual and unique to Vietnam. There were many images combining imagery of both war and nature. A few soldiers crossing a small footbridge in a huge steamy green jungle, for example. Another popular theme was the inclusion of modern elements in what seems at first to be a very traditional painting. Village scenes scattered with communist flags. Fishermen casting nets with freighters and smokestacks in the background. I especially loved the lacquer engraving and lacquer painting in the main building. The use of color and composition by Vietnamese artists is spectacular. It reminded me a lot of Klee, one of my favorite artists.I would have to agree with some of the reviewers who commented on what a shame it was that the building itself is probably not very kind to the art. It didn't appear to be very well climate- or humidity-controlled. Also, the official policy is no photos at all, without the museum director's express consent. I really wish they at least allowed photos without flash. There was so much art I loved and would like to remember. They didn't seem to be enforcing the policy very strongly though, so if you have a camera with a discreet setting, you should be able to quietly sneak in a few shots.There is a cafe on the premises, but I didn't get a chance to check it out. Also free lockers next to the ticket window. Tickets 20,000 dong. Quite a bargain! I might go back to check out their applied art exhibit since I didn't have time to view that. Which reminds me...they started kicking people out as early as 4:45pm, even though closing time is supposed to be 5pm.
People through art. Art there was remarkable. Not only history of it but the present. It takes you through more than 2000 years. Amazing glimpse into the nations roots and greatest achievements.
Amazing collection. Basically had the museum to myself for this visit. An amazing collection of fine arts from many time periods. Not to be missed!

Rich collection. This is a rich collection of pictures, lacquered wooden carvings, statues and other artefacts starting in medieval times and coming right up to date. Some of the pictures are as interesting for the subject matter as for the art, eg the picture of primary school kids practising evacuation during the Vietnam war. So the museum gives a good flavour of the history of Vietnm as well as being full of beautiful things.

Cultural Historic Treasure. The Fine Art Museum is set up in three floors of chronological order with the oldest on the ground floor. Creative masters and their metamorphosing through time and life's experiences.

an absolute treasure in need of TLC. It is difficult not to judge. The Museum is clearly a treasure. I have been a couple of times, although I usually leave feeling a bit of pique. Once, during an exhibition by modern artist Hoang Dinh, I was rewarded with a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, both rare and humbling, to meet the artist and his beautiful wife. I am still in awe. Not only of their gentle hospitality, but of the work itself - breathtakingly beautiful explosions of color and meaning with a very Vietnamese soul. But, I am very sorry to say, the Museum otherwise is a ramshackle. The light bulbs that aren't blown are sputtering and on the brink of extinction. Excruciatingly rare and beautiful national treasures are crumbling from exposure. There is precious little in the way of explanatory notes in English or other languages to identify epic pieces - although what narrative is provided is excellent. I admit I am spoiled by Museums in the West, like the Smithsonian. I can understand the enormous pride that must lie behind such an exquisite collection but I feel only sad at what is wasting away from neglect. I wouldn't complain except I think that maybe an outcry from the public might shake the government to provide the necessary resources to do this institution some justice. Both times I visited the air conditioning was on the fritz (no worry for me, only the art work), the exhibition rooms were filled with the cigarette smoke of bored security guards, and staff spoke loudly on cell phones, oblivious to the hallowed nature of what was on offer. For all that - I will go again. I will take visitors. I urge other visitors to go to. It is an important place. It just needs some help.

Insights into Hanoi's history through art. I thoroughly enjoyed visiting this art museum, more than other sites I visited in Hanoi. I had no expectations, as I have no background in East Asian or Vietnamese art, so everything came as a surprise and delight. The art on display shows a variety of traditional techniques as well as recent forays into more European styles, and gives a rapid overview of several important periods in the nation's history. For a North American visitor, the paintings and sketches from the war period are particularly intriguing, offering a chance to see the war through the other side's eyes. There is a nice shop where you can purchase prints and small originals, and you are left at peace to explore the piles of works on sale.

A wide ranging and enjoyable collection with some real beauties. The Fine Arts Museum contains some truly beautiful artifacts and paintings. There are some particularly striking sculptures and carvings. The painting styles and subjects are wide ranging and engaging. An enjoyable morning spent.

Best museum in hanoi. This museum has the best collection of vietnamese art. It also gives a sense of the nation history. The work done before 1945 was romantic. I love the painting of a young girl sitting next to lily flowers. Then come the paintings of the war period during which it is very propaganda.The museum is next to temple of literature and make it covenient to have smt planned for half a day

Good insight into historical art. We stumbled across this place accidentally but it was a good find...if you are into art. It was a great insight into styles of Vietnamese art over time as well as seeing their history documented. Some fantastic Buddha sculptures

Stunning works of art here. We found ourselves here after we needed shelter from a downpour.We were amazed at the enormity of the centre and the diversity of the collection.Well worth the visit, and allow at least a couple of hours!!

Art museum. we were alittle rushed as we arrived late , but the art and themed rooms were great to see. The American war was such a sad time in Vietnamese history and portrayed in lots of art here - understandably.

Great place to spend a couple of hours. An old French chateau style building holding a range of old and modern art. Some of the 2,000 year old bronze axes and tools are intricately carved and make fascinating exhibits. We saw strong Indian and Viking reflections in some of the stone carvings. The modern pictures were more disappointing but provided an interesting contrast to the older and more detailed works.It's opposite the Temple of Literature so combining this museum with the TOL gardens makes a good trip. The gift shop has some nice if pricy items.

Prepare to Spend a Couple Hours. This museum is deceptively large. There is limited variety of art in Vietnam compared to what we might be accustomed to from the West. What is here is worth the visit, however. You will see the history of Vietnam expressed in art. The museum was much larger than I expected, so prepare to spend a couple of leisure hours wandering through the many floors and sections.

Well worth a visit. This is just across the road from the Temple of Literature, and a lovely old building, so we went in to see what was on offer. It gives a good insight into the various art forms in Vietnamese history, but we especially liked the paintings, which reflect the turbulent history of the country but in a beautiful and creative way. A very worthwhile visit.

Average. I want to see more big paintings and sculpture, but I love some of the paintings, Please ask for the direction before going there, we get lost when we get there since they don't have big signs on the outside
Well worth the visit. saw some amazing art and really appreciated the culture of Vietnam. The place is extremely well run and the staff most helpful. A must for when we comeback
Overwhelming due to the amount of artwork. Was interesting but for each different style there was a large amount of artwork which made it overwhelming. Could have been a lot more concise.
Fantastic and amazing. We roamed around the museum and it was amazing. It was stated there about the life of people in the past and also about the good deeds of Mr. Ho.

Well worth the visit. This was a great museum - the artwork and sculptures are excellent. There is a range of painting styles and the exhibitions are housed in a beautiful building which is worth visiting for the architecture.
great for rainy days.. I think one needs to have a special interest to fully benefit.Generally, not disappointing from a casual point of view. We spent a rainy afternoon there, Quite interesting.
FIne Arts Museum. We spent hours here. It is beautifully laid out and the artworks really tell the story of Vietnam. Highly recommended.

Nice Way to escape the Heat. I went to the Fine Arts Museum one afternoon after a day of sightseeing. It is a 3 story museum with lots of rooms, the museum is a bit outdated but there was a great collection of Vietnamese art. A lot of it referencing the Vietnam War. I really enjoyed the special exhibit which was impressionist art.

Enjoyed it!. We really liked this museum! "The museum is housed in a 1930s French colonial structure, which originally housed the daughters of the French colonial elite who came from all over Indochina to Hanoi to study." Of course, air-conditioned & very peaceful. A bargain at 20,000 VND!

I'm really like Fine Arts Museum. I'm visited the Fine Arts Museum a few day ago. It offers a fascinating spectrum of Vietnamese art, from ancient to very modern. This is a collection of sculptures, ceramics, silk paintings, lacquer paintings and a few oil paintings... I'm really like Fine Arts Museum

A collection of Art!. This is the place to go for all artistic people or perhaps those who enjoy gazing and staring at a piece of art, I enjoyed the sculpture section but the rest of it isn't what fascinate me.However this place is indeed highly recommendable for tourists. VND20,000 for entering.

Unique insight into the fine arts of Vietnam. Great building holding a well curated and high quality selection of paintings, prints, and sculpture .Serene, beautiful and we enjoyed it without any guides or other patrons. 10m people in Hanoi region and we had it all to ourselves!Do yourself a big favour and enjoy this treasure and be humbled by the depth and breadth of the artistic culture of Vietnam

A gem. Therecare some very good exhibits in this amazingly peaceful french collonial building. Leave plenty of time is this is what you like. I stayed for over two hours walking the three floors. In the courtyard is also a nice little restaurant where you can refresh. Located close to the Temple of litterature, its worth the effort to make time for this one.

Fine Arts Museum. The fine arts museum was quite interesting! It was virtually a ghost town which made wandering through the exhibits very relaxing and enjoyable (not to mention that the AC was divine after a morning spent touring the Temple of Literature). The museum itself is under renovation, but still worth the visit.
Fine Arts Museum. The collection of artworks is very interesting, especially the pieces produced after French colonisation and the lacquered works. It was a nice way to spend a steamy afternoon.
very nice art pieces. If you want to visit a quite nice museum : there you are ! very nice peices of local art. Nobody around. the restaurant on the ground floor is excellent.

Undergoing renovations but fascinating nonetheless. The Fine Arts Museum consists of two buildings, one directly across from the main gates and one to the right. The one to the right was mostly textiles and pottery, although the pottery display in the basement was closed due to renovations. The textile displays were moderately interesting.The main building, opposite the gates, had some excellent displays of ancient artifacts, definitely well worth a visit. Also some modern paintings and sculptures.The front gate asks that you leave your knapsacks in a locker in the front gatehouse. We did that initially but after seeing many people carrying their packs and waterbottles around, retrieved our stuff. There was supposed to be an attendant in the locker-room but no one was staffing it.

Another Perspective on Vietnam. Ordinarily I am not into this sort of thing. But the artwork was impressive and varying. It could have done with a few more desciptive palques to give you a greater feel in certain contexts. But I was pleasantly surprised - a welcome way to escape the heat and humidity.
Art and culture. interesting to see what was on display you can see a lot of the red flag in the art work, some beautiful works on display, some of the traditional work is amazing

Very interesting. We were supposed to go to museum of ethnology but it was closed (note most public buildings are closed on Monday's) so went here instead. Lots of interesting art pieces dating back many years, we had a guide who was able to explain in depth about the country's long history

Well worth a visit great contemporary art section. Beautiful building and great location. Only a few dollars for entry makes this a great choice.Lots of rooms to explore. Sure to find something of interest. I enjoyed contemporary gallery.Gift shop is different - piles of pictures and you can meet the artists!

Classic View of Vietnam. Surprisingly un-modern art where the impressions of the American War are naive and simple, but incredibly realistic, depicting the struggle and the committment of the VIet. The historical exhibits belie the modern beliefs, but point back to a more romantic and spiritual time before the conflicts.

Nice place. Probably not a place of must see in Hanoi, but do drop by if you have time or want to find a place to take a respite from the summer heat.The art work and paintings on display are most pleasant if you appreciate the arts. The air con rooms on the ground floor are very cosy and overall I think a very pleasant place to spend an hour or two and learn a bit about Vietnam's history of fine arts.Recommended

If you're interested in art...... if you're interested in ART this is a must see in Hanoi with examples of work from the 11th Century right through to contemporary artists.I loved it and you can get a small book in the shop to remind you of some of the best pieces for 50,000 dong ($2.50)...you can't go wrong.In my Guide book it said there was an entrance fee but on the day I visited I did not have to pay.
