Lighting could have been better, but nice selection or pieces dating back to the 11th century and some modern pieces. One room had short videos as art exhibits. One video showed a drawing on what seemed to be a white board. The artist would throw a rock in the water and the splash of water would dissolve the drawing.Gift shop at the end with a no pressure attendant. Entire place is air-conditioned as was a nice retrieve from the 38 degrees (100 F) outside.

Skip the first floor. Unless you are looking for a historical museum as well skip the first floor, filled with artifacts and all other things I personally found hard to associate with fine arts.The rest of the building provides a decent selection of fine art works, nothing extremely spectacular in my opinion yet worth a visit if you appreciate arts. Do avoid the afternoon in full sun as the a/c units and fans cannot beat the 34 / 38 degrees Celsius in summer.

Great Museum - lots of variety. My husband and I visited this museum in March and had a great experience. We had started our morning with a visit to the Temple of Literature across the street, which was crowded and less impressive than we expected. We decided to try this museum afterwards as an afterthought, but were glad that we did!Given how large the museum is - it covers two buildings with at least three floors each - it felt very manageable. We walked through the whole museum from start to finish and didn't get bored at all. The information cards in English are very informative and helpful in enhancing appreciation of the art and artifacts. The galleries are arranged chronologically, which we found really helpful for grasping the history of fine arts in Veitnam. Definitely recommended.

Great Museum, "World Class" enjoyed it and went back a 2nd time. The art depicted 1000 years of the countries fine arts, and Vietnam has some seriously incredible art. The lacquer medium was demonstrated over a centuries old tradition. The statuary over 300 years old and it's lacquer (all natural form local trees, barks, 23K gold, silver, pigments only found in nature, layered on in over 8 layers, sanded and relaid) was worth the trip alone. A real education. As Le E'cole de Beaux Arts the Parisian University 350+ years old (see: Henri Matisse, etc) has a division in Hanoi for over 90 years now, the museum has Post-impressionism and many other fine paintings the styles of which you will be familiar with. Truly on the top 3 things to do in Hanoi group.

Amazing art work. We walked here from the Temple of Literature as it's not far and we had time to spare and were blown away by the quality of the art work here. Many pieces depicting the time during the war, the most amazing life sized Buddha sculptures...the list goes on. Not a place to be missed - even if, like us, you aren't really into art galleries. The buildings themselves were also amazing.
just a first floor is worth to see. The first floor is really great with the old sculptures and etc,.. the another floors are not a big thing... but I can recommend for everybody visiting the museum.
Fine arts museum. The art work spread out over so much space was interesting, I found some of it repetitive- the frames were gorgeous, and the old building is a treasure.

Notably missing are any more modern, abstract or avante garde pieces, which, in itself is an interesting statement. A full day but a good itinerary for 1 day in Hanoi if you're pressed for time.
Worth a look. Had a wide range of artworks to look at and set out beautifully. It is a pretty big space so we didn't see all of the museum but what we did see was interesting.

Well worth a visit. I was pleasantly surprised by the range of works in the Museum - buddhist sculptures, artifacts, lacquer paintings, silk paintings, folk art, woodblocks. Entrance fee: 20,000 VND ($1). Close by is Temple of Literature also worth a visit. Need a drink or some great food visit KOTO opposite Temple of Literature in Van Meiu Street.

Internal signposting is a little confusing but otherwise a very interesting visit. Not too many visitors when I was there, so very quiet and unrushed. In the front courtyard there is a little restaurant (The Match Box) serving Vietnamese and Western snacks and drinks – all very relaxed and good quality.
Fine Arts Museum. Not on the usual tourist list. A Gem of a gallery and a must see. Our hotel told us about this, so we took their advice.

Not true, though.It quickly gets better, and the museum has a rather impressive collection. Some nice sculptures from the last 2000 or so years, and followed by a comprehensive collection of paintings. There are some very distinct schools: traditional/pre-war, many paintings and installations dating from or after the 1960/70 Vietnam war, strongly socialist-inspired work, and more recent/contemporary art. Overall not a huge, but well selected set of works that oen can see in about an hour. Well worth it.There is also a bookshop wiht a well-chosen collection of books on art, with a focus on Vietnamese art. The manager is the wife of an artist herself, and very knowledgeable herself (with pretty good English). There is also a lot of original art on sale - teh best collection I was able to find in Hanoi, where "copy shops" abound, and where finding original work is very hard. Prices are moderate to a bit high, starting at 100 US$ for smaller pieces, and with larger oil- or laquer works going for 500+ $. Worth a visit if you have the time. Spent about an hour here checking out the local art. There wasn't many people around and the pathway through the gallery is a little confusing but there are plenty of art works to view.There is certainly a major emphasis on revolutionary art and Vietnamese propaganda but it doesn't necessarily detract from the enjoyment of seeing some nice works.The gallery is a little away from the city centre but if you enjoy art and have the time you will appreciate a visit
Interesting museum. Definitely worth visiting. Older art was interesting although nothing especially remarkable. However, we were impressed by the contemporary art.

a bit of a bore. Several floors were closed, there is no plan to carry around and the staff seemed more intent on knitting than directing one. Loads of toilets/ dear gift shop(s) which appear to be run by comercial groups not museum. Very near to Museum of Literature so go there instead unless you are really into Communist war propaganda and socialist art asian style
Fine arts. Interesting -not well frequented by travellers Picture vietnamese art focussed more on recent times The war is a constant theme

Pleasantly surprised. I honestly was not expecting much (and was expecting a lot of French/European art) but was pleasantly surprised at the great collection of Vietnames fine art. Very interesting if you are into art.. Interesting to see the art from hundreds of years ago, which is very different to European art. Western influences only appear in more recent times. You can see the influence of caricatures throughout the centuries is still prevalent today on Vietnamese art.

Brilliant. Gorgeous building. I could have sat outside and just stared at the building and architecture all day ...The displays are incredible and very well marked. In particular, we enjoyed the bronze work and statues. HIGHLY recommend this as part of your itinerary.

Beautiful Exhibits. My husband and I really liked the exhibits, and the how much was on exhibition. However, we found the way the staff sat round in the galleries in groups talking very loudly rather unprofessional. Very National, indeed. Previous reviewers have not always emphasized that this is really the National Fine Arts Museum of Hanoi, and that only Vietnamese Art is on display. The upper floor is largely devoted to ancient art, mainly in the form of statues of Buddha and other Buddhist themes, as well as some impressively colorful silk tapestries.The ground floor holds a large collection of paintings, drawings and photographs, as well as a number of relatively modern sculptures in stone and wood that reveal commendable technical skill and occasional artistic vision. The most interesting rooms exhibit paintings and drawings from the time of the Vietnam War to the present. Initially, one is struck but not surprised that they start off as pure propaganda vilifying the Americans and glorifying the communist state in a grotesque imagery borrowed from Stalinist and Fascist Art. Whatever colors the artist may have used, everything comes across metaphorically as black or white. The art of the post-war period is more lyrical and even poetic at times; the subject matter is ordinary people going about their business of restoring normality to the battered country, or conventional landscapes of the countryside. But since the beginning of the new Millenium, propaganda and social realism have taken a back seat. The influence of cubism and abstract expressionism shows in many of the best works, and it would be hard to recognize their provenance. This suggests that " Bourgeois Formalism", the biggest sin an artist could commit in the Eastern Europe of the 1950s to '80s, doesn't trouble the current Vietnamese Communist Party, and that control of ideological thought and expression has regressed from that of Orwell's 1984 back to a more normal liberal framework. You could say that on the time frame of the avant gard chronometer, Hanoi has reached about 1960 Greenwich Village Time. There will still be a few decades before their artists try to pass off elephant dung and dirty beds as works of creative art.

An amazing collection and very fine building - not to be missed. One of my real Hanoi favourites - this is a superb Fine Arts Museum, full of stunning paintings and a rich array of very fine classical sculpture. Located near the Temple of Literature (Van Mieu), so easy to combine with the usual city high-point visits. Vietnamese oils from the 1920s to the later 20th century are a revelation, and the collection of ancient sculpture is also very fine. The moving works of 20th century war art are particularly compelling. It's quite a go-ahead place with a children's activity centre and periodic exhibitions: I do strongly recommend a visit.

A fine tradition. The Museum contains many works of art spanning the history of Vietnam. I was unaware of the great tradition of Vietnamese art until i visited this Museum and the fine arts museum in Ho Chi Minh City. Particularly beautiful are the lacquer on wood paintings. There is also a great collection of sculptures and ceramics.

Excellent view of Vietnamese art. Although many of the older paintings in this museum are badly in need of restoration, the contemporary work is really terrific. Skip the dreadful social realism rooms, but don't miss the decorative arts wing. The building itself is a fine example of French colonial architecture.

Truely something to experience if you are interested in art. Experiencing the history and seeing how the Vietnamese artists project their history and culture in their art work was a real enriching experience. Never have I visited an art museum where the culture and history of a nation is projected and reflected in their visual art as at this place. A truely enriching experience

broad collection. we enjoyed the layout of this gallery- 2 buildings, 1 with ancient vietnamese ceramics and the other with more contemporary art. It was interesting seeing the development of artistic styles. The "American" war is heavily featured and very thought provoking.
Not special. Nice to see some old stuff but not really worth a visit. Thr museum is very old and old fashioned. I did see things i have seen in ethnic, war or other musea as well
Culturally relevant. Loved seeing Vietnamese art prior to the twentieth century. Well recommended with the Vietnamese Museum of Ethnology.

Fine Arts Museum. I enjoyed this museum that contains a collection of ancient works from VietNam as well as an ample collection of Twentieth Century paintings and sculptures. The works offer a glimpse into the struggles and sufferings of the Vietnames peoples during the last 70 years of liberation struggles.

Worth a visit but lower your expectations on presentation. This museum in my opinion is a must. Vietnamese art is pretty amazing and you will see a lot of it on display here. From painting on silk, to lacquer work to statues etc. Gives you an interesting idea into the development of the country, however the artworks are not explained and there is very little information. I was excited too about the museum shop as I wanted to buy some art to find a sultry employee who spoke no European language and could not explain any of the artworks.However I would still visit the museum again.

One stop center for historical artifacts and artwork. For a minimal entrance fee, we enjoyed the displays which encompassed art, sculptures and old ceramics and traditional wares. It would be nicer if more details were in English.

An interesting place. A big museum with a lot of diferents arts inside. It's not my hobbie but it was a good moment for me, and not too much tourist, so perfect!Just one thing the translation in French is not really good but better than nothing.
Freshen it up. Poor presentation. Neglected, badly lit and not enough fine arts represented. Older historical section on sculpture, Buddhas etc, was the most interesting. Needs to be freshened up.
worthwhile. not much on the contemporary side; lots of war-influenced art; some great expressive sculptures of buddhist figures

Amazing art, fantastic museum. The pieces displayed here range from antique items to contemporary artworks. Lots of stuff to see, you can't get bored in this museum. If you're not an art fan, I suggest you try a different kind of museum, but for an art enthusiast, this place is a must-see. Great for watching as art progressed from early centuries to modern times. You can also buy different souvenirs and artworks when you visit, and the fee for gaining access is insignificant. Costumes, sculpture, paintings, there are many different aspects of art put on displayed there, and the museum is well organized in sections. Very nice!

lovely. Some of the work was quite beautiful and the displays were lovely. A German tourist moved a sign asking visitors not to take flash photography so that he could snap away taking half a dozen or more flash photographs ; weird.Take a coffee in the shaded cafe area

Much more impressive than expected. This is a very comprehensive museum, covering a couple of thousand years of artworks, including fabrics, clothing and ceramics as well as sculpture and paintings. There's so much to see, it's worth taking a break in the shady coffee shop, as it can be quite warm inside. Do give yourslef enough time to see everything - we went late in the day and had to rush some of the exhibits. Don't miss the powerfully striking bronze 'Memorial' by Nguyen Phu Cuong.
Really well done. great museum. covers all aspects of Vietnamese art. very well organized. we spent 3 hours there, but are really interested in art

Lovely suprise. I really wanted to see Vietnamese art as I really have not recognized any in Australia before. I must say I really love what I saw. beautiful paintings on silk and I dont mean scarves , landscapes portraits fine but delicate. I certainly bought certain colours back with me that really represent Vietnam for me.
Amazing lacquer work. The museum was very diverse and I especially liked the lacquerwork, it was amazing. The propaganda posters were very poignant.
Well worth a trip.. Highly recommend a walk around this museum and the contemporary art is a real highlight. Lacquer work and wood cuts

A look at history through art. the building was nice and the presentations had a nice flow to it. To me the contemporary war art was what I liked best. The use of art to spread propaganda was one of the highlights. Great cafe in which we had a good lunch in the grounds.

Good experience -tracing history and art of Vietnamese. This was a little empty of people when we went for some reason, but we really enjoyed going round it. Each room was laid out in a chronological order so you got a really good progression of art, culture and history of the Vietnamese. I really enjoyed it. I hope people don't miss this out on their itinerary!

Fine Arts Museum. It was interesting to see the art but there was a surprising amount of pictures about the wars in Vietnam. I liked the room with differnt cultural dress over time anf the models of differnt houses.

Contemporary and traditional art. I liked this museum because it traced the history of Vietnam's art through the ages, ending with a very worthwhile contemporary art exhibition. The curio shop also had some nice trinkets to take back home.

pleasant surprise filled with emotional art. We had no idea what we would find. The paintings, on the 2nd floor especially, were amazing. So nice to see the subjects of art not be from the West. Interesting blending of Asian and European styles. Lots of images of war that hit home given Vietnam's 20th century strife. Worth the visit.

An address you shouldnt miss it in Hanoi. It's very well display. There are many nice master pieces to see and beautiful sculptures and painting. It will take at least one hour to see all painting on 3 floors at the museum.

Nice overview of Vietnamese art and culture.. This museum of fine art is definitely worth going to if you are at all interested in art. It chronicles the art of the country from antiquity to modern times sequentially and is housed in an old colonial building.
A MUST SEE!. This is a great collection of art. You can trace Vietnam's history from floor to floor as you enjoy the museum. Put this on your itinerary.

Lovely way to while away a couple of hours. My husband and I enjoyed wondering though the Art Museum and seeing the world from a very different perspective. I'm glad we didn't take our teenagers, as this meant we had a more peaceful time and could linger.
The on site restaurant is very good quality, worth a trip.
Very enjoyable.. Really interesting, not crowded, and full of treasures and laquerwork. I particularly liked the ancient sculptures. (try Matchbox restaurant in the grounds too!)
Early Budhist art. Lovely place to come, esp if its wet. Tour groups do not seem to come here so you can appreciate the art in peace and quiet. a great range of art from 11th century-20c

Unbelievable Carved Lacquer Paintings. For less than USD1 you can gain entry into the Fine Arts Museum and spend an hour or 2 wandering about the beautiful (if chaotically curated) pieces. As other reviewers have mentioned, the signages are very confusing, and you’ll find yourself backtracking as you navigate the rooms. Their rules about photography are also confusing, we were told at the entrance that we could take pictures and then minutes later admonished by another security guard and told no pictures. You can stash your camera and belongings in the free luggage lockers at the entrance. Do look out for the Buddha statues on the ground floor and the stunning carved lacquer work paintings on the 2nd floor
nice but expected more. I have been there with full expectation like other museum.The palce is nice nice and there are some amazing paiting.But personaly I was expected more about.

Beautiful And Eccectic Works of Art. The museum, located in two French Colonial buildings, is confusing to navigate and lacks sufficient signage. I first had to figure out where to pay the admission fee, and how to enter the building. The rooms are chopped up and there was no English guides material that I could see. That being said, many beautiful pieces are displayed, including lacquerer ware, paintings, folk art, sculpture etc. i most enjoyed the beautiful collection of buddhist monks, realistic and haunting. Do find them you will be amazed.

Made an impression. It really made me realize the depth of Vietnamese art history and scene. Unlike other Asian art, European influence is visible and very interesting. I wish there were more signs and informational material on the art pieces throughout the museum though. It was a bit difficult because there is such little explanation.
Interesting stuff. This is the best art gallery we have been to for a while, well worth a visit - and nice and cold inside too
Some beautiful works. If you feel like an art museum, this is definitely worth a look. Lots of beautiful works and of course some interesting communist influences.

Interesting museum for art lovers. If you like art or are experienced in Vietnam History this is a great museum, otherwise bring a good guide as the museography is not that great. You'll see interesting pieces of art, and it is a good break from Hanoi's heat

Decent collection across several centuries. The pieces of art are presented in chronological order allowing one to get a sense for the historical development. But they are focused mainly on the colonial history, the Vietnam war and to a smaller extent on traditional Vietnamese life. After a while, each piece seems to meld into another and not much stands out. If you have been to art museums in Europe and at expecting something of that caliber, you will be disappointed. But if you are wanting to get some idea of evolution of Vietnamese art over the centuries, you may find this a reasonable way to spend a few hours.

Worth a visit. Once you've paid your 20,000d (bargain) to the miserable cashier (she's so grumpy and rude it's actually hilarious) there are two buildings to explore. Personally I was less interested in the old relics and bits of champa pottery but it's useful context to fine art in Vietnam. Some good thought provoking pieces on the upper floors of the main building.Unfortunatley two floors of the second building were being reinstalled (no discount!?) when we visited but we still poked about a bit and think that both floors will be impressive once completed.

Vietnamese Art at its best. The museum has a great collection of Vietnamese art. Although English is limited, the collection on display is wonderful. One of the art dealers in an adjacent building in the second floor has a great collection of art for sale.

Endless stairs and small rooms. but they show a wide range of Vietnamese art, and especially the dark side. Would have liked better English descriptions but read up a little to gain better insight. Fabulous old wooden statues/
Worth a look. The only disapointment was the lack of information about some of the displays. Well displayed easy to follow and interesting.

I want to take 5 days and rectify the translations all over the Museum.. While in Vietnam I came across an article that discussed that "Art in Vietnam is not on decline for it had to have reached a peak. It is in its infancy."
Worth the visit for your own verdict.

Much better than I expected. Today we went with HanoiKids to the Museum of Fine Arts in Hanoi. And even though I did not have high expectations from such a museum in Vietnam, I was very surprised to find such beautiful paintings and statues. The building itself was a dormitory during the french period and is not conceived as a museum, and thus the rooms are not always connecting. Downstairs are the antiques. Upstairs wooden laquered statues and paintings from the early 20th century, with modern times paintings on the 3rd floor. Lots of really beautiful paintings all by Vietnamese artists. The museum is also a quiet place where you can spend an hour away from the hectic city.

Good place to kill a couple of hours. Just like other historical monuments in Hanoi, the Vietnam Fine Arts Museum is worth the trip to kill time and be surrounded by wonderful paintings strongly influenced by its culture and history. The modern paintings at the third and fourth floor are worth the visual trip.
Great museum. I found this very interesting and you can quite clearly see the influence of the great painters in some of the styles of the Vietnamese painters.

Very big!. Very interesting and various. Clean and quiet. The building is nice, too. But the organisation is a little messy and it is quite big. From antiquity to contemporary times, you will find every kind of things you could find in a museum. If you like paintings, go directly upstairs, there are plenty of them and you would save a lot of energy!20000 VND in June 2012

War and culture. A visit to this museum really brings home the effect of previous wars on the people and culture of Vietnam in a contemplative atmosphere. Easily reached when combined with a visit to the Temple of Literature and not very busy.

interesting socialist art. Art gives a context to a countrys history, and you can see it here. there was also a temporary contemporary art show on here from other asian artists which was fascinating in April.
.. Big and organized collection, a little bit of everything (contemporary art and ethnic clothes as well).Really enjoyed sculpture collection

Splendid array of the old and new.. Artworks ranging from the ancient (few thousand years old) to the new (20th century) was a delight to see. Ancient sculptures of dragons, lions, buddhas, and wonderfully decorated ancient doors were nice to see on the first level. Then the more recent artworks on silk, oil painting, wood-lacquering was brilliant.

OMG - World class art. Was blown away by the moving and technically brilliant art in this gallery. Rooms and rooms of great lacquer work paintings (unique to Vietnam I think) glows with mood and mystery, this gallery just HAS to be seen, on a par with European museums featuring far more well known masters. Worth a visit!

History lesson. The fine arts museum has an extensive history of Vietnam through art works. To walk through each stage totally inmerses you in this rich and complex history story. It also contains more contemporary works and exhibitions of Vietnamese artists. There's also a shop with great art works at affordable prices, great souvenirs and reminders of Vietnam's rich culture.

You should not miss it once you are in Hanoi.. The hanoi art museum is one of the best place to visit. In this place, you are fascinated by the evolution of vietnamese art, from traditional art like Dong Ho art, Hang Trong Art ( a kind of wood engraving on Do paper), to lacquer paintings - very special vietnamese artwork, and of course modern art. Nowadays, there is an other kind of painting made from the very popular class of people, the embroidery painting. This is not only a place you can find the works of almost all the famous painter of Vietnam, but you can also understand and across the evolution of the society and the daily life of vietnamese people, through art and age of picture. A meaningful trip across the culture of the country.Nice visit!
Probably better when all floors open. Two floors, the one's we were most interested in, were closed while undergoing display upgrades. What we did see was a bit ordinary.

wonderful. Did not have enough time for all of this one so it is on my list for the next trip for sure. It has some beautiful things in the place and art is what makes things go around go and enjoy the sights!

Beautiful Artwork. The museum is in two buildings that offer two different flavors of art. The main building offers some amazing contemporary pieces mixed with historical paintings. I gained a greater understanding of the mood from each period. The other building contained modern art installations with some interactive exhibits. The basement of this building contained antiquities.

Excellent Collection.. We walked from our hotel in the Old Quarter - so very accessible.The 'standing' collection is excellent, particularly the collection relating to Buddhism stretching back into antiquity.The Exhibition on 'River Life' showing when we were there was challenging - very 'modern' and gave us cause to think.
this is a great museum in Hanoi. wow, it is a must do in Hanoi, one of the best MUST DO in Hanoi and it is just empty since no hanoians are interested.
Excellent. Lovely building - loads to see from prehistoric to modern day art. Particularly loved the Buddha statues
Nice displays. Some very nice displays of ancient, contemporary and political artwork in a quiet building in this loud and busy city.
Beauty of Art. I like this Museum very much, it show me a lot of beautiful art.

Needs more respect. A great museum in Hanoi, but it is concerning that you can touch the exhibits easily, showing a lack of respect for the exhibits, some of which are thousands of years old.
Well worth a visit.

Combine with your trip to the Temple of Literature. Just across the road from the back end of the Temple of Literature. Some good art by Vietnmese artists including some good painting from the French and war periods and some very good sculpture - look out for the different depictions of the Buddha.
Art history lesson. See Vietnamese art history and how it has developed over the centuries.Sadly it is underfunded and this is demonstrated by the poor framing
Mediocre - rather unloved. We were almost the only visitors to this large Art gallery. Some very nice pieces but a rather neglected and unloved feel to the place, Too much propoganda art.

Very nice collection. This is a very interesting collection of works. Gives insight into the war years as well as other more accessible art pieces. There is a tremendous gift shop selling original works too.
Look down. Just walking around looking at the tiled floor was a joy!

a great collection of Vietnamese art. This was a real surprise. I enjoyed the historical/antique sculptures and statues the best. Paintings were good too, though. This is well worth spending 1-2 hours wandering around.

A small museum with some astonishing pieces. I have been here before and last time I appeciated the paintings a great deal. This time it was the extraordinary lacquer work. Both times the few stone staues they have really make me smile. An easy museum to go through and enjoy.

Lovely. You'll see the evolution of art in Vietnam over the years. They showcase a lot of lovely traditional to contemporary pieces. You'll see sculptures, remnants of old pagodas and different paintings (silk, lacquer, oil, wood, and mixed media ). It was a very interesting visit!

Worth a Visit...Surprised by Breadth of Artwork. We enjoyed seeing the breadth of the collections of paintings, sculptures and other artwork at this museum. It sprawls over three plus floors and basement in the other wing. Our favorites were the hand carved lacquer paintings from the 1960's. In some of the rooms, there was a large focus on war related material that may or may not be to your liking. For us, we tended to go faster through these rooms and enjoyed the buddhas and other historical pieces. It's worth a visit and is a nice place to relax from the busy Hanoi streets.TIP: This is very close to the Temple of Literature so we visited both when on that side of town. In between them is KOTO restaurant (worth a stop for lunch) and a NGO selling Handicrafts (also worth a stop).

lovely, underrated museum. my friend and I both enjoyed our peaceful walk around the exhibits here - strange it seems so neglected. Also nice shop with work by local artists and a great little cafe and wine bar for lunch.
Great. Great art museum. they always show great paintings

Another view into Vietnam , a charming museum. This well maintained museum, housed in an impressive but charming building shows at one hand some nice pieces from their huge collection objects from the past and ethnics. The room with the wooden statues of monks is very expressive.The most interesting part consists of the rooms with all vietnamese paintings of the last two centuries that show how western art rules were translated into vietnamese and show at the same time very nice scenes out of daily life. Surprising is the abundant presence of battle scenes and related.It is very close to the Temple of lLiterature and Restaurant Koto, so it is difficult to find out a reason not to go

Interesting View Into Vietnamese Art. The Museum has three floors in the main building. The first floor is antiquities and the second and third floor are paintings, prints and sculpture. In the second building the third floor has a large beautiful ethnology display, not to miss, and the first two floors houses traveling exhibits and the basement has ceramics. Since the museum was started in the 1960’s the bulk of the newer work is from the 60’s and 70’s. The museum has created a visual adventure into early art of Vietnam, and a look into in to the changes of the country in the 1960’s and 70’s. My greatest disappointment is the lack of Vietnamese art of the 1800’s and early 1900’s and they seem not to be collecting, at present, the wonderful contemporary art of the country. There are so many wonderful artists in Vietnam; they need to be shown in their museum. With all that said, I strongly recommend a visit to this unique art museum.
Beautiful Art. The varied exhibits were colourful in many ways and gave us a very interesting introduction to Hanoi.
great to see. heaps to see here can spend a lot of time in here our quide was very good here ,showing us around

Too focused on army theme. Although I enjoyed the visit, I guess I expected something else. It seems too much of the exhibits are concentrated on art with army themes... I am not personally into that.
Fascinating and beautiful. All mediums of art and organic craftExtremely memorable and well worth a visit !!
A clear slant.. The curators of this museum have a clear slant - much of the art work celebrates soldiers and their fight against the "American Aggressors" but still, it is an interesting visit.

Mildly diverting. Floors are arranged chronologically from bottom to top. Building is noteworthy, perhaps needing some TLC. I mostly enjoyed the contemporary pieces, some were quite memorable. It was very quiet which is an attraction in itself, an escape from the hurley burley of motorbike mayhem. There is a nice cafe by a shady tree in the grounds. A pleasant place to chill out and allow the visual attractions to be absorbed.
Excellent. Not one to visit this type of museum but this one is well worth it. Fabulous artifacts
A surprise. Old and new art was easily viewed, very few attendees, some wonderful modern art too. . .the crafts people and artisans in Vietnam are incredibly skilled
You should go if you're interested. It's actually an OK Museum considering that most of the VN museums are terrible.

lovely 20th century paintings of rural vietnam and historical. We thoroughly enjoyed this art gallery with some amazing pictures ant other sculptures definitely worth a vist if you like any form of art

Defininetly worth a visit for the art and the gift shop as well.. This is a museum not only about art but also a window into Vietnamese culture and the impact of centuries of war. There are some wonderful exhibits - the Buddhist statues are fascinating, particularly those of the Buddha himself which show him as emaciated rather than fat and jolly. As I looked at these statues I felt like this must have been how Buddha actually looked; and many of the other figures looked individual as well. The lighting is poor and the building shabby but there are still artworks that would hold up in any museum. Also fascinating were how many of the paintings and sculptures referred to war. This is a country that has been invaded many times, by many different armies, over many different time periods. A lovely statue with a classical feel is holding a rifle...this juxtaposition is seen in many works. And if you like to shop, the small store of the museum has some of the best things to buy that we saw on our tour of the country. Many folks told us, 'if you see something, buy it." you may not see it again and we were glad we listened to that advice. The museum is definitely worth a visit as much for its window on the culture as anything else.

Really Vietnam. Capitals have art museums and most have the European, Japanese, American masters. This museum just across the street from the popular Temple of Literature, is really local. The beautiful French era building is full of relics, not all well-preserved, from the pre-colonial, 20th century colonial and revolutionary times. IT's a lovely building and a great window on their culture.The garden area is a welcome respite from the noisy street.

The buddha sculptures alone are worth a visit. Well worth a visit. Things we liked included an exhibition of modern work by contemporary artists, the textiles floor showcasing hill-tribe costumes that inspired us to go to Sapa and some great rice-paper prints which we later saw being sold in the Old Quarter's Ancient House.

Interesting collection. From ancient to contemporary, folk arts and domestic art, this collection is spread across two buildings and three floors. I was a bit "museumed out" by the time I got here and still enjoyed it. I also enjoyed the quiet - a respite from the noise of the city!

Thoughtfully displayed, suprisingly deep collection. We were pleasantly surprised at this museum, which is far better than equivalent institutions in Delhi and Beijing in providing consistently attractive displays and detailed, English-language explanations of the works on display. The ground-floor galleries are a must-visit, with encyclopedic coverage of Vietnam's cultural history and its distinct regional identities. Several major wood carvings were a real joy, and merited far more time than the hour or so we had before the building closed. The middle floor also had some treasures in store, particularly the lacquer paintings from the early 20th century. One monumental set of screens is truly memorable, unexpectedly rich not only in color but in design and artistic insight. But it's also on the second floor that the propaganda starts to seep in, not unexpectedly given Vietnam's 20th-century experience. On the third floor it becomes relentless. Brilliant technique is no help to an aesthetic language that ranges from the bombastic (the inevitable shot-down planes) to the insipid (Norman Rockwell-in-Hanoi images for the Jane Fonda set at their most witless). Our big regret is that we were not able to get to the adjoining building housing craft exhibits, or to see any contemporary galleries, which I hope would show the arts growing past their Uncle Ho-era stridency. But the bottom line: highly recommended, with managed expectations.

the national museum with living artists. I used to work around the corner so I visited this place quite a lot......all of the major schools of art in the last 150 years are represented here....except.....they are dated probably 50years after the schools came into existence...for example impressionism (1870's/1880's) but the school of impressionism in Vietnam seems to be dated 1920/30........also, this is probably one of the few national galleries where you have a chance of accidentally bumping into somebody outside in the coffee-shop who has work hanging on the walls inside the gallery..........if you can get over the obvious propagandist/nationalist role of these artworks and appreciate them (even if some of the schools of art arose in Vietnam sometime later than they appeared in Europe or America)....the artworks are interesting and beautiful...........they also give an interesting insight into developments in Vietnamese history.....there is also an interesting collection of carved Buddhas saved and preserved for posterity from temples all over Vietnam.....also for the aficionados, the collection of lacquer wares and painted silks is beautiful and worth the visit......the museum has a very active conservation unit and there are constantly different exhibitions of new art-works throughout the year.........a visit to the museum can easily combined with a trip to the Temple of Literature and makes a good cultural day out in Hanoi.

could be better.. I took my class here as a field trip, so I am keeping that in mind. I get that the Viet are working with what they have, and it is nice that they place the museum inside an old french villa, but that leaves certain design flaws. The museum is a bit tricky to navigate, and unfortunately after awhile, it becomes pretty mundane. Because of the gov't here, the arts doesn't get the best funding, and the art that has survived from the past is slightly...narrowly focused on said gov't. So once you get to the section about Modern Vietnam it become all propaganda and boring. There is some amazing art there, don't get me wrong, and I wasn't expecting for it to rival The Tate, but I was quite let down.

If you are interested in art this is a must!. A chronological trip through vietnamese art - just enough info in each room (in VN, French and English), well labelled pieces, very well lit and displayed. We spent four hours following the arrows round and may well go back. There are beautiful ancient sculptures, fascinating late C18th pieces, and the C20th galleries were extremely interesting, tracing the development of outside influences, and particularly of course showing the effects of the war(s) on the artistic sensibility. We really were dead impressed by this place! (And the museum shop was just fine, as was the elegant cafe outside!)

Definitely worth a visit. This museum is close to the Temple of Literature (Van Mieu) and so easy to reach. The rather dated presentation of the museum and lack of information up front does not diminish from the outstanding collection of both historic and modern (late 19th-20th century ) Vietnamese art, if you can get them to provide a room plan which gives you the chronological sequence for a visit (start ground floor on the right). A very satisfying and revealing experience. There is not much of contemporary artists on show, and the gallery of art for sale is a serious anticlimax.

Average art museum. This is a collection of sculptures, ceramics, silk paintings, lacquer paintings and a few oil paintings. None of the exhibits really struck me as anything special, but it is a fair diversion for a couple of hours.

Not essential. Located in a remarkable 1930ies building, the Fine Arts Museum has three floors. Ground floor offers a limited number of interesting sculptures from 10th to 19th centuries as well as a small collection of archeological artifacts. Particularly impressive are Buddhist deities such as the huge "One Thousand Eye, One Thousand Arm Guan Yin" statue. However some of the lacquered statues seem to have been so poorly "restored" - maybe with acrylic paint (you can even spot dried paint drops on faces) - that it spoils the pleasure of admiring them. The first and second floors display modern and contemporary paintings and a few sculptures. At least every second one represents armed soldiers or military tanks. I agree that "fine arts" is a matter of subjectivity, but honestly some artworks in these two floors are of questionable artistic value and appear out of place in a museum of fine arts. They would better be placed in the nearby Army Museum. In summary, if you are used to visiting fine arts museums around the world, the Fine Arts Museum of Hanoi might disappoint you, even when the admission fee is almost symbolic (20'000 dongs or 1 US$) . Has restrooms. Restaurant on premisses.

An excellent museum. We visited the Fine Arts Museum a few years ago. In my travel log, I wrote that the couple of hours we'd spent there hadn't been enough, so next trip we're planning to spend an entire morning or afternoon. It offers a fascinating spectrum of Vietnamese art, from ancient to very modern. In many parts, the displays and lighting are on a par with modern western galleries and museums. Probably not suitable if you're only going to Vietnam for cheap beer, Ha Long Bay and cheap Ts :-)

Pleasant but empty. Seemed to be the only tourists in the place. Interesting sculptures and textiles, but if your home city has a world-class museum, it would be okay to skip. Gift shop has things that you can find elsewhere in Hanoi. Pretty building, but certainly not a must-see.
Interesting Sculpture, Paintings and Folk Art. I really enjoyed my visit to this Museum, it was quiet and cool and the art an interesting mixture of sculpture and painting. Definately recommended.
